batch.name: Campbell Ch9 Cellular Respiration and Fermentation — Olympiad Expansion

questions.question: During the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDC) reaction, pyruvate is oxidatively decarboxylated to acetyl-CoA. Which cofactors are required for this multi-step reaction?
options: Only NAD+ and CoA are required for the complete reaction
The reaction requires only thiamine pyrophosphate and water
Only ATP and NADPH are needed because the reaction is anabolic

Five cofactors are required: thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) for decarboxylation, lipoamide for acyl transfer and oxidation, CoA for acetyl group acceptance, FAD for reoxidation of dihydrolipoamide, and NAD+ as the terminal electron acceptor
questions.explanation: The pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDC) is a massive multi-enzyme complex (~10 MDa in eukaryotes) consisting of three catalytic components: E1 (pyruvate dehydrogenase/decarboxylase), E2 (dihydrolipoyl transacetylase), and E3 (dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase). The reaction proceeds through five steps requiring five cofactors: (1) E1 uses thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP, derived from vitamin B1) to decarboxylate pyruvate, forming a hydroxyethyl-TPP intermediate. (2) The hydroxyethyl group is transferred to lipoamide (covalently attached to E2 via a lysine residue), oxidizing it to an acetyl-thioester while reducing the disulfide of lipoamide. (3) E2 transfers the acetyl group from lipoamide to coenzyme A (CoA, derived from pantothenic acid/vitamin B5), forming acetyl-CoA. (4) E3 reoxidizes dihydrolipoamide using FAD (derived from riboflavin/vitamin B2) as an electron acceptor. (5) FADH2 is reoxidized by NAD+ (derived from niacin/vitamin B3), producing NADH. The flexible lipoamide arm of E2 swings between all three active sites, acting as a substrate channel. This is NOT an anabolic reaction (C) — it is oxidative and catabolic. It requires all five cofactors, not just two (A, D).

questions.question: In the citric acid cycle, the conversion of isocitrate to alpha-ketoglutarate by isocitrate dehydrogenase is a key regulatory step. Which combination of effectors correctly describes its regulation?
options: Activated by ADP and NAD+ (signaling low energy charge); inhibited by ATP and NADH (signaling high energy charge)
This enzyme is constitutively active and not subject to any regulation
Activated by ATP and NADH; inhibited by ADP and NAD+
Activated only by calcium ions with no other regulatory inputs
questions.explanation: Isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH) catalyzes the first oxidative decarboxylation in the TCA cycle: isocitrate + NAD+ → alpha-ketoglutarate + CO2 + NADH. As one of the three primary regulatory enzymes of the TCA cycle (along with citrate synthase and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase), IDH is allosterically regulated by the cell's energy status. ADP is a positive allosteric activator — its accumulation signals that ATP has been consumed and more energy is needed, stimulating TCA cycle flux. NAD+ availability also promotes the reaction as a substrate. Conversely, ATP is an allosteric inhibitor — high ATP indicates energy sufficiency, slowing the cycle. NADH inhibits both as a product (mass action) and allosterically, signaling that the electron transport chain has sufficient reducing equivalents. In some tissues, Ca2+ also activates IDH (particularly the mitochondrial NAD+-dependent isoform IDH3), linking TCA cycle activity to muscle contraction and hormonal signaling. Option A reverses the regulatory logic. The enzyme IS regulated (C). While Ca2+ does activate it, it is not the only regulator (D).

questions.question: The chemiosmotic hypothesis proposed by Peter Mitchell explains ATP synthesis by oxidative phosphorylation. Which statement most accurately describes this mechanism?
options: ATP is synthesized by direct substrate-level phosphorylation using high-energy intermediates in the electron transport chain
ATP is produced by the direct chemical coupling of electron transfer to phosphorylation without any intermediate energy form
The gradient is formed by pumping potassium ions, not protons

Electron transport through the ETC complexes pumps protons from the mitochondrial matrix to the intermembrane space, creating an electrochemical gradient (proton-motive force) composed of both a pH gradient (delta-pH) and a membrane potential (delta-psi); protons flow back through ATP synthase (Complex V), which uses the energy of this gradient to drive the mechanical rotation of its rotor and catalyze ATP synthesis
questions.explanation: Peter Mitchell's chemiosmotic hypothesis (1961, Nobel Prize 1978) revolutionized bioenergetics by proposing that the energy of electron transport is conserved as an electrochemical proton gradient across the inner mitochondrial membrane, not as a high-energy chemical intermediate (as the chemical coupling hypothesis proposed) or a conformational change (as the conformational coupling hypothesis proposed). The proton-motive force (pmf or delta-p) has two components: (1) delta-psi — the membrane potential (approximately -180 mV, matrix negative), which is the dominant component in mitochondria, contributing approximately 80% of the pmf. (2) delta-pH — the pH gradient (approximately 0.5-1 pH unit, matrix more alkaline), contributing approximately 20%. The relationship is: delta-p = delta-psi - (2.303RT/F)delta-pH. Complexes I, III, and IV of the ETC pump protons across the inner membrane as electrons flow downhill through the chain. ATP synthase (F1Fo-ATPase) then uses the pmf to drive rotational catalysis — protons flowing through the Fo channel cause the c-ring to rotate, which drives conformational changes in the F1 catalytic subunits (binding change mechanism, Boyer) that synthesize ATP from ADP + Pi. This is NOT substrate-level phosphorylation (A). There IS an intermediate energy form — the pmf (C). Protons, not K+ ions, are pumped (D).

questions.question: Rotenone (a Complex I inhibitor), antimycin A (a Complex III inhibitor), and cyanide (a Complex IV inhibitor) all block electron transport. If antimycin A is added to actively respiring mitochondria, which ETC components become more reduced and which become more oxidized?
options: All components become fully reduced because electron flow is completely blocked
All components become fully oxidized because the block prevents any reduction
Only Complex III is affected; all other components function normally

Components upstream of the block (Complex I, CoQ, and the Rieske iron-sulfur protein of Complex III upstream of the Qi site) become more reduced because they cannot donate electrons past the block; components downstream (cytochrome c, Complex IV, and O2) become more oxidized because they can no longer receive electrons
questions.explanation: Antimycin A specifically blocks electron transfer in Complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) at the Qi site (quinone reduction site on the matrix side), preventing the transfer of electrons from cytochrome bH to oxidized ubiquinone. This creates a bifurcation in the redox state of the ETC: UPSTREAM components (Complex I, ubiquinone pool, and the first half of the Q-cycle in Complex III — including the Rieske iron-sulfur protein and cytochrome c1 on the Qo side) become progressively more REDUCED. Electrons continue to flow from NADH into Complex I and through to ubiquinone, but cannot pass the antimycin A block. The ubiquinone pool becomes fully reduced (QH2 accumulates). Complex I also becomes reduced because its electron acceptor (Q) is unavailable. DOWNSTREAM components (cytochrome c, Complex IV including cytochrome a, cytochrome a3, and CuA/CuB centers) become more OXIDIZED because they continue to transfer any remaining electrons to O2, but receive no new electrons from the blocked Complex III. O2 is already the most oxidized component and remains so. This differential redox response is a classic experimental approach for mapping the order of electron carriers in the ETC. Not all components become fully reduced (A) — downstream ones become oxidized. Not all become oxidized (C). The block affects the entire chain, not just Complex III (D).

questions.question: The P/O ratio (number of ATP molecules synthesized per oxygen atom reduced) differs for NADH and FADH2. What are the approximate P/O ratios and why do they differ?
options: FADH2 has a higher P/O ratio than NADH because FADH2 is a stronger reducing agent
P/O ratios are identical for all substrates because ATP synthase operates at a fixed rate

NADH has a P/O ratio of approximately 2.5 and FADH2 approximately 1.5, because NADH donates electrons at Complex I (pumping 4 H+), while FADH2 donates at Complex II (pumping 0 H+) — this means NADH-derived electrons drive proton pumping at Complexes I, III, and IV (total approximately 10 H+), while FADH2-derived electrons only drive pumping at Complexes III and IV (total approximately 6 H+); with approximately 4 H+ needed per ATP, this gives approximately 2.5 and 1.5 ATP per atom of oxygen
Both NADH and FADH2 have P/O ratios of exactly 3.0 because they both donate 2 electrons
questions.explanation: The P/O ratio reflects the stoichiometry of ATP synthesis coupled to oxygen reduction, and it differs for NADH and FADH2 because they enter the ETC at different points. NADH (E'0 = -320 mV) donates electrons to Complex I (NADH dehydrogenase), which pumps 4 H+ per pair of electrons. Electrons then pass through ubiquinone to Complex III (pumping 4 H+ via the Q-cycle) and through cytochrome c to Complex IV (pumping 2 H+ while reducing 1/2 O2 to H2O). Total: 10 H+ pumped per NADH. FADH2 (E'0 = -220 mV) donates electrons to Complex II (succinate dehydrogenase), which does NOT pump protons — it simply transfers electrons to ubiquinone. Electrons then pass through Complexes III and IV as above. Total: 6 H+ pumped per FADH2. ATP synthase requires approximately 4 H+ per ATP (3 for the rotational catalysis + 1 for the Pi/ATP translocase). Therefore: NADH P/O = 10/4 = 2.5; FADH2 P/O = 6/4 = 1.5. Note these are non-integer values, correcting the older textbook values of 3 and 2. The difference is NOT because of electron number (A) — both donate 2 electrons. NADH is actually the stronger reducing agent, giving it the higher P/O ratio (C is backwards). P/O ratios differ based on entry point (D).

questions.question: During alcoholic fermentation in yeast, pyruvate is converted to ethanol in two steps. What is the biological purpose of this pathway?
options: To produce ethanol as a nutrient for the yeast cells
To consume excess acetaldehyde that accumulates during aerobic respiration
To generate additional ATP beyond what glycolysis produces

To regenerate NAD+ from NADH so that glycolysis can continue under anaerobic conditions — without NAD+ regeneration, glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase cannot function and glycolysis halts, eliminating all ATP production
questions.explanation: Fermentation pathways (both alcoholic and lactic acid) serve one essential purpose: regeneration of NAD+ from NADH under anaerobic conditions. Glycolysis requires NAD+ at the glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase step (reaction 6). Under aerobic conditions, the NADH produced is reoxidized by the electron transport chain. Under anaerobic conditions, without a functional ETC, NADH accumulates and NAD+ becomes depleted. Without NAD+, GAPDH cannot function, glycolysis stops, and no ATP can be produced — a lethal situation for obligate fermenters. In alcoholic fermentation: (1) Pyruvate decarboxylase (using TPP) converts pyruvate to acetaldehyde + CO2. (2) Alcohol dehydrogenase reduces acetaldehyde to ethanol using NADH, regenerating NAD+. The pathway does NOT generate additional ATP (A) — fermentation produces 0 ATP beyond the 2 from glycolysis. Ethanol is a waste product, not a nutrient (C) — indeed, it is toxic to yeast at high concentrations (>12-15%). Acetaldehyde does not accumulate during aerobic respiration (D) — it is specifically an intermediate of the fermentation pathway.

questions.question: The Q-cycle in Complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) is essential for efficient proton translocation. What is the net result of one complete Q-cycle?
options: The Q-cycle transfers electrons backward from cytochrome c to ubiquinone

For each pair of electrons transferred from QH2 to cytochrome c, the Q-cycle oxidizes two QH2 molecules at the Qo site and reduces one Q to QH2 at the Qi site, resulting in the net translocation of 4 H+ to the intermembrane space and the transfer of 2 electrons (via two cytochrome c molecules) to Complex IV
One QH2 is oxidized to Q, transferring both electrons to cytochrome c and pumping 2 H+ across the membrane
The Q-cycle directly reduces oxygen to water at the Qi site
questions.explanation: The Q-cycle (proposed by Peter Mitchell, refined by structural studies) is an elegant mechanism that doubles the number of protons translocated per pair of electrons through Complex III. It operates in two half-cycles: FIRST HALF: One QH2 binds the Qo (outer) site. One electron goes to the Rieske iron-sulfur protein → cytochrome c1 → cytochrome c (the high-potential chain). The other electron goes to cytochrome bL → cytochrome bH (the low-potential chain) → reduces Q to semiquinone (Q.-) at the Qi (inner) site. Two H+ from QH2 are released to the intermembrane space. SECOND HALF: A second QH2 binds the Qo site. Again, one electron goes to Rieske → cyt c1 → cyt c (second cytochrome c reduced). The other electron goes through bL → bH → reduces the semiquinone at Qi to QH2 (picking up 2 H+ from the matrix). Two more H+ from the second QH2 are released to the IMS. NET RESULT: 2 QH2 oxidized at Qo, 1 QH2 regenerated at Qi (net: 1 QH2 consumed); 2 cytochrome c reduced; 4 H+ released to IMS (2 per QH2 at Qo); 2 H+ consumed from matrix (at Qi). The Q-cycle does NOT reduce oxygen (C) — that occurs at Complex IV. Electrons flow forward, not backward (D).

questions.question: Uncoupling proteins (UCPs) such as thermogenin (UCP1) in brown adipose tissue dissipate the proton gradient without ATP synthesis. What is the metabolic consequence?
options: UCP1 blocks electron transport, stopping all mitochondrial respiration

The energy stored in the proton gradient is released as heat instead of driving ATP synthesis — electron transport continues (and may even accelerate due to the reduced proton-motive force) but the energy is dissipated as thermal energy for non-shivering thermogenesis
ATP production increases because the proton gradient is maintained more efficiently
Uncoupling proteins pump additional protons to increase the gradient
questions.explanation: Uncoupling proteins (UCPs) are mitochondrial inner membrane carriers that allow protons to flow down their electrochemical gradient from the intermembrane space to the matrix, bypassing ATP synthase. This short-circuits the chemiosmotic coupling between electron transport and ATP synthesis. In brown adipose tissue (BAT), UCP1 (thermogenin) is highly expressed and activated by free fatty acids (released by beta-adrenergic signaling during cold exposure or after sympathetic nervous system activation). When protons leak through UCP1, the proton-motive force decreases, which actually STIMULATES electron transport — the ETC complexes pump protons faster trying to maintain the gradient, consuming more O2 and oxidizing more NADH/FADH2. However, since the energy is not captured as ATP, it is dissipated as heat. This non-shivering thermogenesis is critical for newborn mammals, hibernating animals, and cold-adapted adults. ATP production DECREASES, not increases (A). UCPs allow proton leak, they do not pump additional protons (C). Electron transport CONTINUES and may accelerate; it is not blocked (D). UCP1 is regulated by purine nucleotides (GDP, ATP inhibit) and fatty acids (activate).

questions.question: In the citric acid cycle, succinate dehydrogenase (Complex II) is unique among TCA cycle enzymes. Which statement correctly explains this uniqueness?
options: It is the only TCA cycle enzyme that is an integral inner membrane protein and also functions as Complex II of the electron transport chain — it directly transfers electrons from succinate (via FAD → Fe-S clusters) to ubiquinone without producing NADH, linking the TCA cycle to the ETC
It is the only enzyme in the cycle that uses GTP instead of ATP
It is the only TCA cycle enzyme located in the cytoplasm rather than the mitochondrial matrix
It is the only reversible reaction in an otherwise completely irreversible cycle
questions.explanation: Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH, also called succinate-ubiquinone oxidoreductase or Complex II) is unique because it serves dual functions: it is both a TCA cycle enzyme (catalyzing succinate → fumarate) and an integral component of the electron transport chain (Complex II). All other TCA cycle enzymes are soluble matrix proteins. SDH is embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane and contains: (1) a covalently bound FAD prosthetic group (not NAD+ — this is why the reaction produces FADH2 instead of NADH); (2) three iron-sulfur clusters (Fe2S2, Fe4S4, Fe3S4) that relay electrons from FADH2; (3) a ubiquinone binding site where electrons are transferred to the ubiquinone pool. The succinate → fumarate oxidation (E'0 = +30 mV) is not sufficiently exergonic to reduce NAD+ (E'0 = -320 mV), so FAD (E'0 = -220 mV) serves as the electron acceptor instead. SDH is in the inner membrane, not the cytoplasm (A). Succinyl-CoA synthetase uses GTP (in animals) or ATP, but that is a different enzyme (C). Several TCA reactions are near-equilibrium and reversible (D).

questions.question: The Pasteur effect describes the observation that the rate of glucose consumption decreases dramatically when yeast cells shift from anaerobic to aerobic conditions. What is the biochemical basis for this phenomenon?
options: Oxygen directly inhibits all glycolytic enzymes through oxidative modification
Oxygen competes with glucose for binding to hexokinase, preventing glucose phosphorylation

Under aerobic conditions, oxidative phosphorylation generates approximately 30-32 ATP per glucose (versus 2 from glycolysis alone), so far less glucose needs to be consumed to meet the same ATP demand — additionally, the increased ATP/AMP ratio under aerobic conditions inhibits phosphofructokinase-1, the rate-limiting enzyme of glycolysis
Aerobic conditions cause yeast cells to stop growing, eliminating the need for ATP
questions.explanation: The Pasteur effect (first observed by Louis Pasteur in the 1860s) reflects the integration of glycolysis with oxidative phosphorylation through allosteric regulation. Under anaerobic conditions, fermentation yields only 2 ATP per glucose, so cells must consume glucose rapidly to meet energy demands. When oxygen becomes available, the mitochondrial ETC and oxidative phosphorylation become active, producing approximately 30-32 ATP per glucose — roughly 15-16 times more efficient. Two mechanisms reduce glycolytic flux: (1) THERMODYNAMIC: The cell's ATP demand is met with far less glucose, so less glycolytic flux is needed. (2) ALLOSTERIC: The increased ATP/AMP ratio (from efficient oxidative phosphorylation) inhibits PFK-1, the committed step of glycolysis. ATP binds PFK-1's inhibitory allosteric site, while AMP (which drops under aerobic conditions) no longer activates it. Additionally, citrate (which accumulates when the TCA cycle is active) also inhibits PFK-1. Oxygen does NOT directly inhibit glycolytic enzymes (A). Oxygen does not bind hexokinase (C). Aerobic yeast cells continue growing, often faster than anaerobic ones (D).

questions.question: During substrate-level phosphorylation in glycolysis, the phosphoglycerate kinase reaction transfers a phosphoryl group from 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate to ADP. Why is this reaction thermodynamically favorable despite ATP synthesis being endergonic?
options: The reaction requires input of additional GTP molecules to proceed
Phosphoglycerate kinase directly couples to the electron transport chain for energy
The reaction is driven by high substrate concentrations, not by thermodynamic favorability

1,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (1,3-BPG) is a mixed anhydride (acyl phosphate) with a very high phosphoryl transfer potential (delta-G-zero-prime of hydrolysis approximately -49.4 kJ/mol), exceeding that of ATP (-30.5 kJ/mol) — the transfer of the phosphoryl group to ADP is therefore exergonic with a net delta-G-zero-prime of approximately -18.9 kJ/mol
questions.explanation: Substrate-level phosphorylation depends on using phosphorylated compounds with higher phosphoryl transfer potential than ATP. 1,3-BPG is a mixed anhydride — its C-1 phosphate is an acyl phosphate (carboxylic acid-phosphoric acid anhydride) formed by the preceding glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase reaction. The hydrolysis of acyl phosphates is highly exergonic (approximately -49.4 kJ/mol for 1,3-BPG) because: (1) the products (3-phosphoglycerate + Pi) are stabilized by resonance and charge repulsion relief, and (2) the mixed anhydride bond is thermodynamically unstable due to competing resonance between the carboxylate and phosphate groups. Since 1,3-BPG's phosphoryl transfer potential (-49.4 kJ/mol) exceeds ATP's (-30.5 kJ/mol), the transfer from 1,3-BPG to ADP is thermodynamically favorable: delta-G-zero-prime = (-49.4) - (-30.5) = -18.9 kJ/mol. This is why 1,3-BPG can drive ATP synthesis. The reaction IS thermodynamically favorable (A is wrong about the reasoning). No GTP is required (C). Substrate-level phosphorylation is independent of the ETC (D) — this is a defining distinction from oxidative phosphorylation.

questions.question: The Warburg effect describes the observation that many cancer cells preferentially use aerobic glycolysis (glycolysis followed by lactate production even in the presence of oxygen). What is the proposed metabolic advantage of this seemingly wasteful strategy?
options: Cancer cells have defective mitochondria and cannot perform oxidative phosphorylation
The Warburg effect is an experimental artifact with no biological significance

Aerobic glycolysis, while less efficient per glucose molecule, provides rapid ATP production and supplies biosynthetic precursors (glycolytic intermediates diverted to pentose phosphate pathway for nucleotides, to serine/glycine for amino acids, and to glycerol for lipid synthesis) that support the high proliferative demands of cancer cells
Lactate production kills surrounding normal cells, giving cancer cells a competitive advantage
questions.explanation: Otto Warburg observed in the 1920s that cancer cells consume glucose at rates 10-100 times higher than normal cells and produce lactate even under aerobic conditions (aerobic glycolysis). While this seems metabolically wasteful (2 ATP per glucose versus 30-32 from complete oxidation), it provides several advantages for rapidly proliferating cells: (1) RAPID ATP PRODUCTION: Although less ATP per glucose, glycolysis can produce ATP much faster than oxidative phosphorylation when glucose is abundant. The rate of ATP production can actually exceed that of OXPHOS. (2) BIOSYNTHETIC PRECURSORS: Rapidly dividing cells need building blocks — nucleotides, amino acids, lipids — more than they need maximal ATP. Glycolytic intermediates feed into: glucose-6-phosphate → pentose phosphate pathway (NADPH + ribose-5-phosphate for nucleotide synthesis); 3-phosphoglycerate → serine → glycine → one-carbon metabolism; dihydroxyacetone phosphate → glycerol-3-phosphate → lipid synthesis; pyruvate → acetyl-CoA → fatty acid synthesis (via citrate shuttle). (3) REDOX BALANCE: Maintaining high glycolytic flux with lactate export helps manage the redox balance needed for biosynthesis. Most cancer cells do NOT have fundamentally defective mitochondria (A) — many maintain functional OXPHOS. While lactate acidification of the microenvironment may confer some advantage, this is secondary (C). The Warburg effect is well-established and therapeutically targeted via PET scanning using 18F-FDG (D).

questions.question: Cyanide and carbon monoxide both inhibit Complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase) of the electron transport chain. What is the mechanism of inhibition and why is it lethal?
options: They directly inhibit ATP synthase without affecting electron transport
They inhibit Complex I, blocking NADH oxidation
They increase oxygen consumption, leading to oxidative damage

Cyanide binds to the Fe3+ of cytochrome a3, and CO binds to the Fe2+ of cytochrome a3, both preventing the terminal transfer of electrons to oxygen — this halts the entire ETC (no electron flow means no proton pumping), collapses the proton-motive force, stops ATP synthesis, and causes NADH accumulation that inhibits the TCA cycle
questions.explanation: Complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase) contains two heme groups (heme a and heme a3) and two copper centers (CuA and CuB). The binuclear center of heme a3-CuB is where O2 is reduced to H2O in a carefully controlled four-electron reduction. Cyanide (CN-) binds tightly to the ferric (Fe3+) form of heme a3, while carbon monoxide (CO) binds to the ferrous (Fe2+) form — both block oxygen from accessing its binding site at the terminal electron acceptor. The consequences cascade through the entire metabolic system: (1) Electron flow through the entire ETC stops because all carriers upstream become fully reduced (no terminal acceptor for electrons). (2) Proton pumping ceases because it is coupled to electron transport. (3) The proton-motive force collapses, stopping ATP synthase. (4) NADH and FADH2 accumulate because they cannot be reoxidized. (5) The TCA cycle stops because NAD+ and FAD are unavailable. (6) Cellular ATP drops rapidly, leading to failure of all ATP-dependent processes (ion pumps, biosynthesis, muscle contraction). Death occurs within minutes from respiratory failure. They do NOT inhibit Complex I (A) or ATP synthase directly (C). Oxygen consumption DECREASES, not increases (D).

questions.question: The glycerol-3-phosphate shuttle and the malate-aspartate shuttle both transfer reducing equivalents from cytoplasmic NADH to mitochondria. Why do they yield different amounts of ATP?
options: Both shuttles yield exactly the same amount of ATP because they transfer the same number of electrons

The malate-aspartate shuttle regenerates NADH in the matrix (which enters the ETC at Complex I, yielding approximately 2.5 ATP), while the glycerol-3-phosphate shuttle transfers electrons to mitochondrial FAD (linked to ubiquinone/Complex II level, yielding approximately 1.5 ATP) — the glycerol-3-phosphate shuttle sacrifices energy efficiency for speed
The glycerol-3-phosphate shuttle produces more ATP because FAD is a better electron carrier
The difference is only theoretical and has no physiological relevance
questions.explanation: Cytoplasmic NADH cannot cross the inner mitochondrial membrane (which is impermeable to NADH/NAD+), so shuttle systems transfer the reducing equivalents. MALATE-ASPARTATE SHUTTLE (liver, heart, kidney): Cytoplasmic NADH reduces oxaloacetate to malate (cytoplasmic malate dehydrogenase). Malate enters the matrix via the malate-alpha-ketoglutarate antiporter. Matrix malate dehydrogenase reoxidizes malate to oxaloacetate, regenerating NADH in the matrix. This matrix NADH enters the ETC at Complex I, yielding approximately 2.5 ATP per NADH. Oxaloacetate is returned to the cytoplasm as aspartate (via transamination and the glutamate-aspartate antiporter). GLYCEROL-3-PHOSPHATE SHUTTLE (skeletal muscle, brain, insect flight muscle): Cytoplasmic NADH reduces DHAP to glycerol-3-phosphate (cytoplasmic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, NAD+-linked). Mitochondrial glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (an inner membrane flavoprotein, FAD-linked) reoxidizes glycerol-3-phosphate to DHAP, transferring electrons to FAD → ubiquinone. Since electrons enter at the ubiquinone level (bypassing Complex I), they yield only approximately 1.5 ATP. The glycerol-3-phosphate shuttle is kinetically faster (simpler, irreversible) but thermodynamically less efficient. FAD is NOT a better carrier (C) — it actually yields less ATP. The difference IS physiologically relevant (D).

questions.question: Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex catalyzes a key reaction in the TCA cycle. Which statement about its regulation is CORRECT?
options: It is constitutively active and not regulated by any metabolites
It is regulated solely by oxygen concentration

It is inhibited by its products (succinyl-CoA and NADH) and activated by Ca2+ — this product inhibition ensures that the TCA cycle slows when the cell has sufficient energy carriers and biosynthetic intermediates
It is activated by ATP and inhibited by ADP
questions.explanation: Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase (alpha-KGDH) complex catalyzes the second oxidative decarboxylation of the TCA cycle: alpha-ketoglutarate + NAD+ + CoA → succinyl-CoA + CO2 + NADH. Structurally and mechanistically, it is homologous to the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, using the same five cofactors (TPP, lipoamide, CoA, FAD, NAD+). Its regulation follows a logical energy-sensing pattern: INHIBITION: (1) Succinyl-CoA — product inhibition. When succinyl-CoA accumulates (indicating sufficient biosynthetic precursor supply or downstream congestion), it inhibits alpha-KGDH by competing with CoA at the E2 active site. (2) NADH — product inhibition and energy signal. High NADH/NAD+ ratio indicates the cell has sufficient reducing equivalents. (3) ATP — high energy charge. ACTIVATION: (1) Ca2+ — in mitochondria, Ca2+ concentration increases during muscle contraction and hormonal stimulation, activating alpha-KGDH (as well as isocitrate dehydrogenase and pyruvate dehydrogenase) to increase TCA cycle flux to meet increased energy demand. (2) ADP — low energy charge signal. Option A reverses the regulation. The enzyme IS tightly regulated (C). While oxygen indirectly affects it via NADH/NAD+ ratio, it is not the sole regulator (D).

questions.question: The binding change mechanism proposed by Paul Boyer explains how ATP synthase catalyzes ATP formation. Which description is most accurate?
options: The Fo and F1 components function independently, with no mechanical coupling between them
ATP synthesis requires no conformational changes in the enzyme
ATP synthase uses a simple acid-base catalysis mechanism at a single active site

Each catalytic beta subunit cycles through three conformational states — O (open, releases ATP), L (loose, binds ADP + Pi), and T (tight, catalyzes ATP synthesis) — driven by the rotation of the gamma subunit powered by proton flow through the Fo channel; the energy input is used primarily for product release, not for bond formation
questions.explanation: Paul Boyer's binding change mechanism (Nobel Prize 1997, shared with John Walker) elegantly explains rotational catalysis in ATP synthase. The F1 component contains three alpha-beta heterodimers arranged in a ring around the asymmetric gamma subunit (part of the central stalk). The key insight is that each catalytic beta subunit exists in one of three conformational states at any given time, determined by the rotational position of the gamma shaft: O (open) — low affinity for ligands; this is where ATP is released. L (loose) — binds ADP and Pi loosely. T (tight) — substrates are bound tightly and the equilibrium between ADP+Pi and ATP actually FAVORS ATP formation (Keq approximately 1 on the enzyme surface). The remarkable insight is that the actual phosphoanhydride bond formation is nearly isoenergonic on the enzyme surface — the energy from the proton gradient is used primarily to drive the conformational change from T→O that RELEASES the tightly bound ATP product. Proton flow through the Fo membrane channel drives rotation of the c-ring and attached gamma subunit, causing sequential conformational changes in the three beta subunits. Each 360-degree rotation produces 3 ATP molecules. The mechanism requires both Fo and F1 coupled mechanically (C is wrong). Conformational changes are central to the mechanism (D is wrong). It involves three active sites, not one (B).

questions.question: In glycolysis, the conversion of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate by phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) is the primary regulatory step. Which metabolite is the MOST potent physiological activator of PFK-1?
options: Glucose-6-phosphate, because it is the immediate upstream substrate
ATP, because it provides the phosphoryl group for the reaction
Citrate, because it signals that the TCA cycle needs more acetyl-CoA

Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate (F-2,6-BP), which is produced by PFK-2 in response to insulin signaling and potently activates PFK-1 by increasing its affinity for fructose-6-phosphate and relieving ATP inhibition
questions.explanation: Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate (F-2,6-BP) is the single most potent allosteric activator of PFK-1. It is produced by the bifunctional enzyme phosphofructokinase-2/fructose-2,6-bisphosphatase (PFK-2/FBPase-2). In liver, insulin signaling activates a phosphatase that dephosphorylates PFK-2, activating its kinase domain and increasing F-2,6-BP levels. F-2,6-BP activates PFK-1 by: (1) increasing the enzyme's affinity for its substrate fructose-6-phosphate (lowering K0.5), (2) relieving the allosteric inhibition by ATP and citrate, and (3) shifting the T/R equilibrium strongly toward the active R state. Remarkably, F-2,6-BP activates PFK-1 at concentrations as low as 1 micromolar. Conversely, glucagon signaling (via cAMP-PKA) phosphorylates PFK-2, activating its phosphatase domain, lowering F-2,6-BP, and reducing glycolytic flux. Glucose-6-phosphate is NOT a direct activator of PFK-1 (A). ATP is actually a substrate AND an allosteric inhibitor (at the regulatory site), not an activator (B). Citrate is an INHIBITOR of PFK-1, not an activator (D) — high citrate signals energy/biosynthetic sufficiency.

questions.question: During intense anaerobic exercise, lactate accumulates in skeletal muscle. What happens to this lactate after exercise ceases?
options: Lactate is directly converted to ATP in the muscle cells
Lactate spontaneously decomposes to CO2 and water without enzymatic involvement

Lactate is exported from muscle to blood and taken up primarily by the liver, where it is converted back to glucose via gluconeogenesis (the Cori cycle) — this newly synthesized glucose can then be returned to muscle for further glycolysis, completing the metabolic cycle
Lactate is permanently trapped in muscle and eventually excreted in urine
questions.explanation: The Cori cycle (named after Carl and Gerty Cori, Nobel Prize 1947) is a metabolic cycle that links glycolysis in muscle with gluconeogenesis in the liver. During intense exercise, skeletal muscle produces lactate via anaerobic glycolysis (lactate dehydrogenase reduces pyruvate to lactate, regenerating NAD+). Lactate is exported from muscle via MCT (monocarboxylate transporter) proteins into the bloodstream. The liver takes up blood lactate and converts it back to glucose through gluconeogenesis — a process that requires 6 ATP equivalents per glucose (4 ATP + 2 GTP). This glucose is released back into the blood and can be taken up by muscle for another round of glycolysis. The Cori cycle effectively shifts the metabolic burden of lactate recycling from muscle (which lacks sufficient gluconeogenic enzymes) to the liver (which has abundant gluconeogenic capacity). The net effect is an energy cost — muscle gains 2 ATP from glycolysis, but liver spends 6 ATP on gluconeogenesis, for a net cost of 4 ATP per cycle, paid by the liver's oxidative metabolism. Lactate is NOT trapped in muscle (A) and is not directly converted to ATP (C). Lactate requires enzymatic conversion (D) — it does not spontaneously decompose.

questions.question: Reactive oxygen species (ROS) such as superoxide (O2.-) are generated as byproducts of mitochondrial electron transport. At which Complex(es) is ROS production most significant, and why?
options: Complex V (ATP synthase) is the sole source of mitochondrial ROS
ROS are only produced during anaerobic conditions when the ETC is inactive

Complexes I and III are the primary sites of superoxide generation — at Complex I, electron leak from the FMNH2 or Fe-S clusters to O2 produces superoxide; at Complex III, the unstable semiquinone intermediate at the Qo site during the Q-cycle can donate a single electron to O2
ROS are produced equally at all four complexes of the ETC
questions.explanation: Mitochondrial electron transport is not perfectly efficient — approximately 0.1-2% of electrons leak from the chain and react directly with molecular oxygen to form superoxide anion radical (O2.-), the primary mitochondrial ROS. The two major sites are: COMPLEX I: Electrons can leak from the fully reduced flavin mononucleotide (FMNH2) or from the N2 iron-sulfur cluster when the ubiquinone-binding site is occupied. This occurs particularly during reverse electron transport (when succinate-derived electrons drive NADH reduction at Complex I via a high proton-motive force). COMPLEX III: During the Q-cycle, the ubisemiquinone radical (Q.-) at the Qo site is a thermodynamically unstable species that can donate its unpaired electron to O2, forming O2.-. This is especially problematic when electron flow downstream is impaired (e.g., by antimycin A). Superoxide is released into both the matrix (Complex I, Complex III Qi site) and the intermembrane space (Complex III Qo site). Cells possess antioxidant defenses: superoxide dismutase (SOD) converts O2.- to H2O2, and catalase/glutathione peroxidase converts H2O2 to H2O. Complex II produces minimal ROS. Complex V does not produce ROS (C). ROS production actually increases when the ETC is highly reduced (D is wrong).

questions.question: Glucokinase (hexokinase IV) in hepatocytes differs from hexokinase I found in most tissues. Which property of glucokinase is physiologically significant?
options: Glucokinase has a higher Km for glucose (approximately 10 mM, near blood glucose concentration) and is NOT inhibited by its product glucose-6-phosphate — this allows hepatocytes to increase glucose uptake and phosphorylation proportionally as blood glucose rises after a meal, functioning as a glucose sensor
Glucokinase functions exclusively in glycogen synthesis, not glycolysis
Glucokinase has a much lower Km for glucose (approximately 0.1 mM) than hexokinase I, allowing the liver to phosphorylate glucose only when blood sugar is very low
Glucokinase and hexokinase I have identical kinetic properties and are functionally interchangeable
questions.explanation: Glucokinase (GK, hexokinase IV) has two critical kinetic differences from hexokinases I-III that are perfectly adapted for its role in liver glucose homeostasis: (1) HIGH Km: GK has Km approximately 10 mM for glucose (compared to approximately 0.1 mM for hexokinase I). Blood glucose normally ranges from 4-5 mM (fasting) to 8-10 mM (postprandial). Since GK's Km is near the upper physiological range, GK activity increases nearly linearly with blood glucose over the physiological range. This allows the liver to act as a glucose sensor — increasing glucose phosphorylation (and subsequent glycolysis, glycogen synthesis, and lipogenesis) proportionally as blood glucose rises after a meal. (2) NO PRODUCT INHIBITION: Unlike hexokinases I-III (which are potently inhibited by glucose-6-phosphate at micromolar concentrations), GK is NOT inhibited by G6P. This allows the liver to continue phosphorylating glucose even when G6P accumulates, enabling the liver to serve as a glucose buffer. Additionally, GK displays sigmoidal kinetics (Hill coefficient approximately 1.7) and is regulated by glucokinase regulatory protein (GKRP) that sequesters GK in the nucleus when glucose is low. GK mutations cause MODY-2 diabetes. Option A has the wrong Km and reasoning. Options C and D are factually incorrect.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about glycolysis:
S1: Glycolysis occurs in the cytoplasm and does not require oxygen
S2: The net energy yield from glycolysis is 4 ATP and 2 NADH per glucose molecule
S3: Phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) is the committed step enzyme and primary regulatory point of glycolysis
S4: Glycolysis consists of 10 enzymatic reactions divided into an energy-investment phase (reactions 1-5) and an energy-payoff phase (reactions 6-10)
options: TFTT
TTTT
TFTF
TTFT
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE: Glycolysis (from Greek 'glycos' = sweet, 'lysis' = splitting) is an ancient metabolic pathway that occurs entirely in the cytoplasm (cytosol) of the cell. It does not require oxygen and can function under both aerobic and anaerobic conditions. This is consistent with its evolution before atmospheric O2 accumulated. All 10 glycolytic enzymes are soluble cytoplasmic proteins (except for some that associate with the outer mitochondrial membrane or cytoskeletal elements). S2 is FALSE: While the energy-payoff phase produces 4 ATP (2 from phosphoglycerate kinase, 2 from pyruvate kinase) and 2 NADH (from glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase), the energy-investment phase consumes 2 ATP (hexokinase and PFK-1). The NET yield is therefore 2 ATP and 2 NADH per glucose, not 4 ATP. The statement says 'net energy yield' of 4 ATP, which is incorrect. S3 is TRUE: PFK-1 catalyzes fructose-6-phosphate + ATP → fructose-1,6-bisphosphate + ADP. This is the first committed step of glycolysis (glucose-6-phosphate from hexokinase can enter other pathways like PPP or glycogen synthesis, but F-1,6-BP is committed to glycolysis). PFK-1 is the primary regulatory target, controlled by ATP (inhibitor), AMP (activator), citrate (inhibitor), and fructose-2,6-bisphosphate (most potent activator). S4 is TRUE: Glycolysis comprises 10 reactions in two phases. The investment phase (reactions 1-5) uses 2 ATP to phosphorylate glucose to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate and split it into two triose phosphates. The payoff phase (reactions 6-10) generates 4 ATP and 2 NADH from the two triose phosphate molecules.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about the citric acid cycle:
S1: The TCA cycle produces 3 NADH, 1 FADH2, and 1 GTP (or ATP) per turn from one acetyl-CoA
S2: Oxaloacetate is consumed stoichiometrically and must be continually resynthesized from dietary sources
S3: Anaplerotic reactions such as pyruvate carboxylase (pyruvate + CO2 → oxaloacetate) replenish TCA cycle intermediates that are removed for biosynthesis
S4: The TCA cycle operates exclusively in the mitochondrial matrix, with all enzymes being soluble proteins
options: TFTT
TFTF
TTFF
TFFT
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE: Each turn of the TCA cycle (from one acetyl-CoA) produces: 3 NADH (at isocitrate dehydrogenase, alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, and malate dehydrogenase), 1 FADH2 (at succinate dehydrogenase), and 1 GTP (at succinyl-CoA synthetase; in some tissues, ATP is produced instead). The overall equation per acetyl-CoA: acetyl-CoA + 3 NAD+ + FAD + GDP + Pi + 2 H2O → 2 CO2 + 3 NADH + FADH2 + GTP + CoA. S2 is FALSE: Oxaloacetate is NOT consumed stoichiometrically — it is regenerated with each turn of the cycle. The cycle begins when acetyl-CoA condenses with oxaloacetate to form citrate (citrate synthase), and after seven more reactions, oxaloacetate is regenerated. OAA is catalytic, not stoichiometric. It does not need to be continually resynthesized from diet — it is recycled. However, when TCA intermediates are withdrawn for biosynthesis (cataplerosis), anaplerotic reactions replenish them. S3 is TRUE: Anaplerotic reactions (Greek 'filling up') replenish TCA cycle intermediates. The most important is pyruvate carboxylase: pyruvate + CO2 + ATP → oxaloacetate + ADP + Pi. This biotin-dependent enzyme is activated by acetyl-CoA — when acetyl-CoA accumulates (from beta-oxidation or amino acid catabolism), it signals the need for more OAA to keep the cycle running. Other anaplerotic reactions include glutamate dehydrogenase (glutamate → alpha-ketoglutarate) and various transaminases. S4 is FALSE: While most TCA cycle enzymes are in the matrix, succinate dehydrogenase (Complex II) is an integral inner membrane protein, not a soluble matrix enzyme. Its FAD prosthetic group is covalently bound, and it directly interfaces with the ubiquinone pool of the ETC.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about oxidative phosphorylation:
S1: The inner mitochondrial membrane has a very low permeability to protons, which is essential for maintaining the proton gradient
S2: Oligomycin inhibits ATP synthase by blocking the proton channel in the Fo subunit, preventing proton flow and stopping ATP synthesis
S3: Under normal coupling conditions, inhibition of ATP synthase by oligomycin will also inhibit electron transport because the proton gradient builds up to a level that thermodynamically opposes further proton pumping
S4: FCCP (carbonyl cyanide-p-trifluoromethoxyphenylhydrazone) is an ATP synthase activator that increases ATP production
options: TTTF
TTTT
TTFT
TFTT
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE: The inner mitochondrial membrane has an exceptionally low proton permeability, approximately 10^6 times lower than typical biological membranes. This is essential because the proton-motive force (approximately 200 mV) would rapidly dissipate if protons could leak back freely. The membrane's high content of cardiolipin (a four-acyl-chain phospholipid unique to this membrane) contributes to its impermeability. Protons can only return to the matrix through specific channels — primarily ATP synthase (productive) or UCPs (for thermogenesis). S2 is TRUE: Oligomycin (a macrolide antibiotic from Streptomyces) binds to the c-subunits of the Fo channel, physically blocking proton translocation. Without proton flow, the F1 catalytic subunits cannot undergo the rotational conformational changes needed for ATP synthesis. Oligomycin is a classic experimental tool for studying chemiosmotic coupling. S3 is TRUE: This demonstrates the tight coupling between electron transport and ATP synthesis. When oligomycin blocks proton return through ATP synthase, protons pumped by the ETC accumulate in the IMS, increasing the pmf. As the pmf rises, it becomes thermodynamically more difficult (and eventually impossible) for the ETC complexes to pump additional protons against the larger gradient. Electron transport therefore slows and eventually stops. This respiratory control demonstrates that the ETC and ATP synthase are coupled through the proton gradient. S4 is FALSE: FCCP is NOT an ATP synthase activator — it is a chemical uncoupler (protonophore). FCCP is a lipophilic weak acid that carries protons across the inner membrane, short-circuiting the proton gradient and PREVENTING ATP synthesis. It dissipates the pmf as heat, similar to UCPs but in an unregulated manner.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about fermentation and anaerobic metabolism:
S1: Lactic acid fermentation in human muscle produces L-lactate (not D-lactate) via lactate dehydrogenase
S2: Obligate aerobes can switch to fermentation when oxygen is depleted
S3: In alcoholic fermentation, pyruvate is first decarboxylated to acetaldehyde (by pyruvate decarboxylase, requiring TPP), then acetaldehyde is reduced to ethanol (by alcohol dehydrogenase, oxidizing NADH to NAD+)
S4: Fermentation pathways produce the same total ATP per glucose as aerobic respiration
options: TFTT
TFTF
TTFF
TFFF
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE: Human lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is stereospecific, producing exclusively L-lactate (also called (S)-lactate). The enzyme catalyzes the reduction of pyruvate to L-lactate with concomitant oxidation of NADH to NAD+. D-lactate is produced by certain bacteria using D-specific LDH enzymes. The distinction is clinically relevant because D-lactate accumulation (D-lactic acidosis) can occur in short bowel syndrome from bacterial overgrowth. S2 is FALSE: Obligate aerobes (strict aerobes) CANNOT switch to fermentation — by definition, they require oxygen for growth and energy production. They lack the fermentation enzymes needed for anaerobic ATP production (or their metabolism is too dependent on oxidative phosphorylation). Examples include Mycobacterium tuberculosis and most mitochondria-containing eukaryotic cells (although many eukaryotes are actually facultative and can ferment). Organisms that CAN switch between aerobic respiration and fermentation are called facultative anaerobes (e.g., yeast, E. coli). S3 is TRUE: Alcoholic fermentation proceeds in two steps: (1) Pyruvate decarboxylase (requires TPP/thiamine pyrophosphate as cofactor) removes CO2 from pyruvate to yield acetaldehyde. (2) Alcohol dehydrogenase reduces acetaldehyde to ethanol using NADH as the reductant, regenerating NAD+. This NAD+ regeneration is the essential purpose of the pathway. S4 is FALSE: Fermentation yields only 2 ATP per glucose (net from glycolysis), while aerobic respiration yields approximately 30-32 ATP per glucose — a 15-16 fold difference in efficiency.

questions.question:
Researchers measure oxygen consumption rate (OCR) in isolated mitochondria under different conditions:

Condition | OCR (nmol O2/min/mg protein)
State 1: Mitochondria alone | 5
State 2: + Succinate (substrate) | 15
State 3: + ADP | 85
State 4: ADP exhausted (all converted to ATP) | 18
State 3u: + FCCP (uncoupler) | 110

Calculate the respiratory control ratio (RCR = State 3/State 4) and explain what these states reveal about mitochondrial coupling.
options: RCR = 85/5 = 17; this indicates that ADP controls oxygen consumption independently of substrate availability

RCR = 85/18 = 4.7; this indicates well-coupled mitochondria — State 3 (ADP-stimulated) respiration is approximately 5 times faster than State 4 (resting) because ADP availability limits ATP synthase turnover, which in turn limits proton return to the matrix, which limits electron transport; the high State 3u rate with uncoupler shows the ETC has additional capacity beyond what coupling allows
RCR = 110/18 = 6.1; the uncoupled rate is the only meaningful comparator for coupling efficiency
RCR cannot be calculated from these data because the values are in arbitrary units
questions.explanation: The respiratory control ratio (RCR) is the ratio of State 3 (ADP-stimulated) to State 4 (resting) oxygen consumption, and it is the most widely used measure of mitochondrial coupling quality. From the data: RCR = 85/18 = 4.72, indicating well-coupled mitochondria (typical values for isolated mitochondria are 3-10, depending on substrate and tissue). STATE ANALYSIS: State 1 (mitochondria alone, no substrate): Minimal respiration — only endogenous substrates are oxidized. State 2 (+ succinate): Modest increase to 15 — substrate is available but without ADP, ATP synthase cannot operate, and the high pmf limits proton pumping, restricting electron transport. State 3 (+ ADP): Dramatic increase to 85 — ADP drives ATP synthase, protons flow back through Fo, pmf decreases, and the ETC accelerates to restore the gradient. This is the maximum phosphorylating respiration rate. State 4 (ADP exhausted): Returns to 18 — all ADP has been phosphorylated to ATP, ATP synthase stops, pmf builds up again, restricting ETC. Slightly higher than State 2 due to proton leak. State 3u (+ FCCP): Highest rate at 110 — the uncoupler dissipates pmf completely, removing all thermodynamic back-pressure on the ETC. This represents the maximum capacity of the ETC itself (uncoupled respiration). The fact that State 3u > State 3 shows that under normal coupled conditions, the pmf imposes a kinetic constraint on ETC activity. Option A uses the wrong states. Option C uses uncoupled rate, but RCR is specifically State 3/State 4. Option D is wrong — the units are appropriate for RCR calculation.

questions.question:
A biochemist measures the standard reduction potentials of ETC components:

Component | E'0 (mV)
NADH/NAD+ | -320
FMN/FMNH2 (Complex I) | -300
CoQ/CoQH2 | +45
Cyt c (Fe3+/Fe2+) | +254
O2/H2O | +816

Using these values, calculate the total free energy change for electron transfer from NADH to O2 and explain why this energy is sufficient to drive ATP synthesis.
options: The total delta-E'0 is 816 - (-320) = 1136 mV, and using delta-G'0 = -nF(delta-E'0) where n=2 and F=96.5 kJ/(V*mol), delta-G'0 = -2 x 96.5 x 1.136 = -219 kJ/mol — this is sufficient to drive the synthesis of approximately 7 ATP molecules (at 30.5 kJ/mol each), but only approximately 2.5 ATP are actually produced due to thermodynamic and mechanical efficiency constraints of the proton-pumping and ATP synthase machinery
The energy is insufficient for even one ATP because the voltage change is too small
The free energy change is positive, meaning the electron transfer is non-spontaneous
Each ETC component produces one ATP independently, totaling 5 ATP per electron pair
questions.explanation: The total standard potential difference is delta-E'0 = E'0(acceptor) - E'0(donor) = +816 - (-320) = +1136 mV = 1.136 V. The positive value indicates a spontaneous (exergonic) electron transfer. Using the Nernst equation relationship: delta-G'0 = -nF(delta-E'0), where n = 2 (electrons per NADH), F = 96,485 J/(V*mol) approximately 96.5 kJ/(V*mol). delta-G'0 = -2 x 96.5 x 1.136 = -219.2 kJ/mol. This is a large negative free energy, indicating a highly exergonic process. Theoretically, 219.2/30.5 = 7.2 ATP molecules could be synthesized per NADH if coupling were 100% efficient. In practice, only approximately 2.5 ATP are produced per NADH (P/O ratio = 2.5), giving a thermodynamic efficiency of approximately 2.5 x 30.5/219.2 = 34.8%. The remaining energy is used to maintain the proton gradient at steady state, drive transport processes, and is inevitably lost as heat (second law of thermodynamics). The energy is NOT insufficient (B). The delta-G is negative, meaning the transfer IS spontaneous (C). ATP is not produced independently at each component (D) — energy is conserved as a proton gradient and then used collectively by ATP synthase.

questions.question: A researcher wants to determine whether a new compound acts as an ETC inhibitor, an uncoupler, or an ATP synthase inhibitor. Which experimental approach using isolated mitochondria would distinguish among these three mechanisms?
options: Measure cell viability after 24 hours of compound treatment

Measure oxygen consumption in isolated mitochondria under State 3 conditions (with substrate and ADP): an ETC inhibitor will decrease OCR; an uncoupler will increase OCR above State 3 levels (approaching State 3u); an ATP synthase inhibitor will decrease OCR to State 4 levels. Confirming with a subsequent addition of FCCP (uncoupler) further distinguishes — after an ETC inhibitor, FCCP will not restore respiration; after an ATP synthase inhibitor, FCCP will restore high respiration rate
Simply measure ATP levels in intact cells
Determine the compound's molecular structure and predict its mechanism computationally
questions.explanation: Isolated mitochondria respirometry is the gold-standard approach for mechanistically classifying compounds that affect oxidative phosphorylation. The experimental logic: SETUP: Energize mitochondria with substrate (e.g., glutamate/malate for Complex I, succinate for Complex II) and add ADP to establish State 3 respiration. Then add the test compound. THREE PREDICTIONS: (1) ETC INHIBITOR (e.g., rotenone, antimycin A, cyanide): Blocks electron flow → OCR decreases. Adding FCCP afterward does NOT restore respiration because electrons cannot flow regardless of the gradient. (2) UNCOUPLER (e.g., FCCP, DNP, thermogenin): Dissipates the proton gradient → removes back-pressure on ETC → OCR INCREASES above State 3 (toward maximal ETC capacity). ATP synthesis simultaneously decreases because pmf is dissipated. (3) ATP SYNTHASE INHIBITOR (e.g., oligomycin): Blocks proton return through ATP synthase → pmf builds up → back-pressure slows ETC → OCR decreases to State 4 level. Adding FCCP afterward RESTORES high OCR because the ETC is not blocked — only the coupling is affected. This sequential addition protocol (substrate → ADP → test compound → FCCP) creates a decision tree that unambiguously identifies the mechanism. Cell viability assays (A) cannot distinguish the mechanism. Cellular ATP levels (C) would decrease with all three types. Computational prediction (D) is insufficient without experimental validation.

questions.question: To study the regulation of pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDC) activity in vivo, a researcher proposes using isotopically labeled substrates. Which experimental design would most effectively demonstrate that PDC is regulated by its phosphorylation state?
options: Feed cells with C-14-glucose and measure total CO2 output over time

Compare PDC activity in cell extracts with and without: (1) PDH kinase inhibitor (dichloroacetate/DCA, which inhibits PDK and keeps PDC in the active dephosphorylated state), (2) PDH phosphatase activator (Ca2+ or insulin signaling), and (3) phosphatase inhibitors — then correlate activity with phosphorylation status measured by phospho-specific antibodies or P-32 labeling; additionally, use site-directed mutagenesis of the three phosphorylation sites (Ser-264, Ser-271, Ser-203 on E1-alpha) to non-phosphorylatable alanines to create constitutively active PDC
Measure mRNA levels of PDC subunits by RT-qPCR
Simply add excess pyruvate and measure acetyl-CoA production
questions.explanation: PDC regulation by reversible phosphorylation is a paradigm of metabolic control, and demonstrating this requires multiple complementary approaches. PHARMACOLOGICAL APPROACH: Dichloroacetate (DCA) is a specific inhibitor of PDH kinase (PDK), the enzyme that phosphorylates and inactivates PDC. Treatment with DCA keeps PDC in its dephosphorylated (active) state. If phosphorylation is the regulatory mechanism, DCA treatment should increase PDC activity and acetyl-CoA/NADH production. Conversely, conditions that activate PDK (high acetyl-CoA/CoA, NADH/NAD+, ATP/ADP ratios) should increase phosphorylation and decrease activity. BIOCHEMICAL APPROACH: Direct measurement of phosphorylation status using P-32 labeling (incubate with gamma-P-32-ATP) or phospho-specific antibodies (immunoblotting with anti-phospho-Ser-264 antibodies) correlated with activity measurements provides direct evidence. GENETIC APPROACH: Mutating the phosphorylation sites (Ser→Ala mutations prevent phosphorylation; Ser→Asp mutations mimic constitutive phosphorylation) and measuring the resulting PDC activity definitively establishes causality between phosphorylation and activity. PDH phosphatase (PDP) is activated by Ca2+ and insulin signaling, linking PDC activity to hormonal control. Total CO2 output (A) is too indirect. mRNA levels (C) reflect transcriptional regulation, not post-translational phosphorylation. Simply measuring activity without manipulating phosphorylation state (D) cannot establish a regulatory mechanism.

questions.question: Fatty acids are catabolized by beta-oxidation, which occurs in the mitochondrial matrix. Why can't long-chain fatty acyl-CoA molecules (e.g., palmitoyl-CoA) directly cross the inner mitochondrial membrane?
options: Long-chain acyl-CoA molecules are too large to pass through any membrane channel or transporter, so the carnitine shuttle system is required — fatty acyl groups are transferred from CoA to carnitine by CPT-I (on the outer membrane), transported as acylcarnitine through the inner membrane via the carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase, and then retransferred to matrix CoA by CPT-II
Long-chain acyl-CoAs freely diffuse across both mitochondrial membranes without any transport mechanism
Only short-chain fatty acids require the carnitine shuttle; long-chain ones cross directly
Fatty acids are catabolized in the cytoplasm, not the mitochondrial matrix
questions.explanation: The inner mitochondrial membrane is impermeable to CoA and acyl-CoA derivatives. The carnitine shuttle overcomes this barrier through a three-step process: (1) CPT-I (carnitine palmitoyltransferase I, located on the outer face of the inner membrane/outer membrane): Transfers the acyl group from coenzyme A to the hydroxyl group of carnitine, forming acylcarnitine and releasing free CoA. CPT-I is the rate-limiting step of fatty acid oxidation and is inhibited by malonyl-CoA (the first committed intermediate of fatty acid synthesis, ensuring that synthesis and oxidation do not occur simultaneously). (2) Carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase (an integral inner membrane protein): Transports acylcarnitine into the matrix while simultaneously exporting free carnitine (antiport). (3) CPT-II (on the matrix face of the inner membrane): Transfers the acyl group back from carnitine to matrix CoA, regenerating acyl-CoA in the matrix and releasing free carnitine for recycling. Short-chain and medium-chain fatty acids can actually bypass the carnitine shuttle and enter the matrix directly, so option C reverses the actual biology. Beta-oxidation occurs in the mitochondrial matrix (D is wrong). The shuttle system IS required for long-chain species (B is wrong).

questions.question: The overall equation for cellular respiration is C6H12O6 + 6O2 → 6CO2 + 6H2O. In which specific metabolic reactions are the 6 CO2 molecules released?
options: All 6 CO2 are released during glycolysis when glucose is split

Two CO2 are released during the two pyruvate dehydrogenase reactions (one per pyruvate) and four CO2 are released during the two turns of the citric acid cycle (two per turn, at isocitrate dehydrogenase and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase) — notably, no CO2 is released during glycolysis or the electron transport chain
All 6 CO2 are released during the electron transport chain
Three CO2 are released in glycolysis and three in the TCA cycle
questions.explanation: Tracking the carbon atoms through cellular respiration reveals where each CO2 is produced: GLYCOLYSIS: Glucose (6C) → 2 pyruvate (3C each). No carbon is lost as CO2; all 6 carbons are retained in the two pyruvate molecules. PYRUVATE OXIDATION: Each pyruvate (3C) is oxidatively decarboxylated to acetyl-CoA (2C) + CO2 by the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex. Two pyruvates → 2 CO2. Running total: 2 CO2 released, 4 carbons remaining (as 2 acetyl-CoA). TCA CYCLE (per turn): Acetyl-CoA (2C) + oxaloacetate (4C) → citrate (6C). Isocitrate (6C) → alpha-ketoglutarate (5C) + CO2 (at isocitrate dehydrogenase). Alpha-ketoglutarate (5C) → succinyl-CoA (4C) + CO2 (at alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase). Two turns: 4 CO2. Running total: 2 + 4 = 6 CO2. ELECTRON TRANSPORT CHAIN: No CO2 is released. The ETC transfers electrons from NADH/FADH2 to O2, forming H2O. Thus: 2 from pyruvate oxidation + 4 from TCA cycle = 6 CO2 total. The O2 consumed in cellular respiration is used exclusively at Complex IV to accept electrons and form water — it does NOT appear in CO2.

questions.question: The adenine nucleotide translocase (ANT) exchanges ADP and ATP across the inner mitochondrial membrane. Why does this transport process consume part of the proton-motive force?
options: ANT exchanges ATP4- (out of matrix) for ADP3- (into matrix) — this electrogenic antiport moves one net negative charge out of the matrix, which is driven by and partially dissipates the membrane potential (delta-psi, matrix negative); additionally, the phosphate carrier imports H2PO4- in symport with H+, consuming one proton from the gradient per ATP synthesized
The energy cost is negligible because ATP and ADP have the same charge
ANT is a passive channel that does not consume any energy
ANT transports ATP and ADP in the same direction (symport), which requires ATP hydrolysis
questions.explanation: The adenine nucleotide translocase (ANT, also called ADP/ATP carrier) is one of the most abundant proteins in the inner mitochondrial membrane. It catalyzes an obligatory 1:1 exchange of matrix ATP4- for cytoplasmic ADP3-. This antiport is electrogenic because it results in the net export of one negative charge from the matrix per exchange cycle. Since the membrane potential is approximately -180 mV (matrix negative), exporting a negative charge works against the electrical gradient, requiring energy from the membrane potential. This means one proton's worth of energy from the pmf is consumed for each ATP/ADP exchange. Additionally, the phosphate carrier (PiC) imports inorganic phosphate (H2PO4-) into the matrix via H+ symport, consuming one additional proton per Pi imported. Combined, the transport of ADP + Pi in and ATP out costs approximately 1 H+ equivalent beyond the approximately 3 H+ needed to drive one 120-degree rotation of ATP synthase. This is why the total cost is approximately 4 H+ per ATP synthesized and exported (3 for synthesis + 1 for transport), giving the non-integer P/O ratios of 2.5 and 1.5. ANT is NOT passive (A). ATP4- and ADP3- have DIFFERENT charges (D). The transport is antiport, not symport (C).

questions.question: Pyruvate kinase catalyzes the last step of glycolysis. What makes this reaction essentially irreversible under physiological conditions?
options: The conversion of PEP to pyruvate releases a large amount of energy (delta-G-zero-prime = -31.4 kJ/mol) because the product pyruvate immediately tautomerizes from the enol to the thermodynamically stable keto form — this spontaneous tautomerization makes the overall reaction highly exergonic and effectively irreversible; gluconeogenesis must bypass this step using pyruvate carboxylase and PEPCK
The reaction is freely reversible and operates near equilibrium in all tissues
Pyruvate kinase requires oxygen to function, making it irreversible only under aerobic conditions
The enzyme is too slow to catalyze the reverse reaction
questions.explanation: Pyruvate kinase catalyzes: PEP + ADP → pyruvate + ATP. The large negative delta-G-zero-prime (-31.4 kJ/mol) and the even more negative actual delta-G in vivo (approximately -23 kJ/mol) make this reaction essentially irreversible under physiological conditions. The thermodynamic driving force comes from two sources: (1) Substrate-level phosphorylation of ADP to ATP (consuming approximately -30.5 kJ/mol of the PEP hydrolysis energy). (2) The spontaneous tautomerization of enolpyruvate (the initial product) to the much more stable keto form of pyruvate, which contributes an additional large exergonic driving force. This keto-enol tautomerization is spontaneous and essentially irreversible, pulling the overall equilibrium strongly toward product formation. Because this reaction is irreversible, gluconeogenesis cannot simply reverse it. Instead, two enzymes are needed to bypass it: (1) Pyruvate carboxylase (pyruvate + CO2 + ATP → oxaloacetate, in the mitochondrial matrix) and (2) PEPCK (oxaloacetate + GTP → PEP + CO2, in cytoplasm). This two-enzyme bypass costs 2 high-energy phosphate bonds (1 ATP + 1 GTP) versus the 1 ATP gained by pyruvate kinase. The reaction is NOT near equilibrium (C). It does not require oxygen (D). The enzyme catalytic rate is not the issue (A).

questions.question: Which amino acids can be converted to acetyl-CoA and thus are classified as purely ketogenic (cannot produce net glucose through gluconeogenesis)?
options: Alanine and glutamate, because they are the most abundant amino acids

Leucine and lysine are the only purely ketogenic amino acids — they are degraded exclusively to acetyl-CoA and/or acetoacetyl-CoA, which cannot be converted to net glucose in animals because the pyruvate dehydrogenase reaction is irreversible and acetyl-CoA cannot be carboxylated to pyruvate
Glycine and proline, because they are the simplest amino acids
All 20 amino acids are glucogenic; none are purely ketogenic
questions.explanation: Amino acids are classified based on the fate of their carbon skeletons: GLUCOGENIC amino acids yield pyruvate or TCA cycle intermediates (oxaloacetate, alpha-ketoglutarate, succinyl-CoA, fumarate) that can produce net glucose through gluconeogenesis. KETOGENIC amino acids yield only acetyl-CoA or acetoacetyl-CoA, which CANNOT produce net glucose in animals. The key reason is that the pyruvate dehydrogenase reaction (pyruvate → acetyl-CoA) is irreversible in animals, and there is no pathway to convert acetyl-CoA back to pyruvate or any gluconeogenic precursor. The two carbons of acetyl-CoA that enter the TCA cycle are lost as 2 CO2 (at isocitrate dehydrogenase and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase) before oxaloacetate is regenerated, so there is no NET carbon gain. ONLY TWO amino acids are purely ketogenic: LEUCINE and LYSINE. Both are degraded exclusively to acetyl-CoA and/or acetoacetyl-CoA. Several amino acids are both glucogenic and ketogenic (isoleucine, phenylalanine, threonine, tryptophan, tyrosine) because their catabolism yields both glucogenic and ketogenic intermediates. Alanine and glutamate are glucogenic (A). Some amino acids ARE purely ketogenic (C). Glycine and proline are glucogenic (D).

questions.question: Complex I (NADH-ubiquinone oxidoreductase) is the largest complex in the ETC. How many protons does it pump per pair of electrons transferred from NADH to ubiquinone?
options: Complex I does not pump protons; it only transfers electrons

4 protons per electron pair — the mechanism involves a conformational coupling between the electron transfer in the peripheral arm (containing FMN and 8 Fe-S clusters) and the proton translocation in the membrane arm, linked by a long lateral helix that transmits conformational changes to four proton channels
10 protons per electron pair, accounting for all proton pumping in the ETC
2 protons per electron pair
questions.explanation: Complex I (NADH dehydrogenase) is an L-shaped enzyme with approximately 45 subunits in mammals (14 core subunits, 31 supernumerary). It consists of a hydrophilic peripheral arm (extending into the matrix) where electron transfer occurs, and a hydrophobic membrane arm where proton translocation occurs. ELECTRON TRANSFER PATH: NADH → FMN → N3 → N1b → N4 → N5 → N6a → N6b → N2 → ubiquinone. The 8 iron-sulfur clusters span approximately 95 angstroms, relaying electrons from FMN to the ubiquinone-binding site near the membrane surface. PROTON PUMPING: 4 H+ are translocated per 2 electrons. The coupling mechanism involves conformational changes rather than direct redox-linked proton translocation (unlike Complex III's Q-cycle or Complex IV's direct proton transfer). A long amphipathic helix (the 'piston' helix) in the membrane arm transmits conformational changes from the electron transfer events to four proton half-channels (three in NuoL/M/N-type antiporter-like subunits and one at the interface with the peripheral arm). With 4 H+ at Complex I, 4 H+ at Complex III (Q-cycle), and 2 H+ at Complex IV, the total is 10 H+ per NADH. Not 2 H+ (A) — that would be insufficient for the observed P/O ratio. Not 10 H+ (C) — that is the total for the entire chain. Complex I DOES pump protons (D).

questions.question: Citrate synthase catalyzes the first reaction of the TCA cycle. Why is the condensation of acetyl-CoA with oxaloacetate to form citrate thermodynamically favorable?
options: The reaction is near equilibrium and is not thermodynamically favorable
The reaction is endergonic and requires ATP input to proceed
Citrate synthase uses GTP hydrolysis to drive the reaction forward

The hydrolysis of the thioester bond of acetyl-CoA (delta-G-zero-prime approximately -31.4 kJ/mol) provides a large exergonic driving force that makes the overall condensation reaction highly favorable (delta-G-zero-prime = -32.2 kJ/mol) — the citryl-CoA intermediate is first formed, then the thioester is hydrolyzed, releasing CoA and pulling the reaction forward
questions.explanation: Citrate synthase catalyzes an aldol condensation followed by a thioester hydrolysis: Acetyl-CoA + Oxaloacetate + H2O → Citrate + CoA-SH. The reaction proceeds in two steps: (1) The methyl carbon of acetyl-CoA attacks the carbonyl of oxaloacetate, forming the intermediate citryl-CoA (enzyme-bound). This condensation step alone would not be sufficiently exergonic to drive the reaction forward. (2) Citryl-CoA is hydrolyzed to citrate + CoA-SH. The hydrolysis of the thioester bond of citryl-CoA (similar to acetyl-CoA hydrolysis, delta-G-zero-prime approximately -31.4 kJ/mol) provides a large free energy decrease that makes the overall reaction highly exergonic (delta-G-zero-prime = -32.2 kJ/mol). This is a common thermodynamic strategy — coupling an unfavorable condensation to a favorable thioester hydrolysis to drive the overall reaction forward. The reaction is NOT endergonic (A). No GTP is needed (C). The reaction is far from equilibrium with a large negative delta-G (D), making it one of the three irreversible regulatory steps of the TCA cycle. Citrate synthase is regulated by substrate availability (oxaloacetate, acetyl-CoA) and product inhibition (citrate, succinyl-CoA, NADH).

questions.question: The energy charge of a cell is defined as ([ATP] + 0.5[ADP]) / ([ATP] + [ADP] + [AMP]). A typical healthy cell maintains an energy charge of approximately 0.85-0.90. What happens to metabolic pathways when the energy charge drops significantly?
options: All metabolic pathways shut down to conserve energy
The energy charge has no effect on metabolic regulation
Anabolic pathways accelerate to build emergency energy stores

Catabolic pathways (glycolysis, beta-oxidation, TCA cycle) are stimulated while anabolic pathways (gluconeogenesis, fatty acid synthesis, glycogen synthesis) are inhibited — the enzymes at regulatory steps of catabolic pathways are activated by AMP/ADP and inhibited by ATP, while biosynthetic pathway enzymes show the opposite regulatory pattern
questions.explanation: The energy charge concept (proposed by Daniel Atkinson, 1968) provides a unified framework for understanding how cells coordinate hundreds of metabolic reactions in response to energy status. The energy charge ranges from 0 (all AMP) to 1 (all ATP), with normal cells maintaining approximately 0.85-0.90 through precise feedback regulation. When energy charge DROPS (more AMP/ADP relative to ATP): CATABOLIC pathways are STIMULATED: (1) PFK-1 (glycolysis) is activated by AMP and ADP, inhibited by ATP. (2) Isocitrate dehydrogenase and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase (TCA cycle) are activated by ADP, inhibited by ATP and NADH. (3) Pyruvate dehydrogenase is activated by decreased ATP/ADP ratio. (4) AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) is activated, phosphorylating and activating catabolic enzymes while inhibiting anabolic ones. ANABOLIC pathways are INHIBITED: (1) Acetyl-CoA carboxylase (fatty acid synthesis) is inhibited by AMPK phosphorylation. (2) Glycogen synthase is inhibited. (3) Gluconeogenesis is inhibited (fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase inhibited by AMP). The cell does NOT shut down all pathways (A) — it selectively upregulates energy-producing ones. Anabolic pathways decrease, not increase (C). Energy charge is central to metabolic regulation (D).

questions.question: Dinitrophenol (DNP) was once used as a weight-loss drug but was banned due to its dangerous side effects. How does DNP cause weight loss, and why is it dangerous?
options: DNP increases appetite, causing weight gain, not loss
DNP directly burns fat by reacting with lipid molecules in adipose tissue
DNP blocks glucose absorption in the intestine, causing weight loss from malnutrition

DNP is a lipophilic weak acid that acts as a protonophore — it carries protons across the inner mitochondrial membrane, uncoupling electron transport from ATP synthesis; the cell compensates by oxidizing more fuel (fats, carbohydrates) to maintain ATP levels, generating heat instead of ATP; it is dangerous because the dose-response curve is steep and unpredictable — slight overdose causes life-threatening hyperthermia, and there is no antidote
questions.explanation: 2,4-Dinitrophenol (DNP) is a classic chemical uncoupler. Its mechanism: DNP is a lipophilic weak acid (pKa approximately 4.0). In its protonated form (DNP-H), it dissolves in the inner mitochondrial membrane's lipid bilayer and diffuses to the matrix side. In the alkaline matrix (pH approximately 8), it releases its proton. The deprotonated form (DNP-) is still lipophilic enough to diffuse back to the IMS (due to electron delocalization across the nitro groups), where it picks up another proton. This continuous cycling dissipates the proton gradient. METABOLIC CONSEQUENCES: Without a functional pmf, ATP synthase cannot produce ATP at normal rates. The cell senses falling ATP levels and responds by: (1) Activating AMPK, stimulating catabolic pathways. (2) Increasing substrate oxidation (glycolysis, beta-oxidation, TCA cycle). (3) The ETC runs at maximal rate (no back-pressure from pmf). All this fuel oxidation generates heat rather than ATP — causing weight loss from fat burning but also hyperthermia. DANGER: The therapeutic window is extremely narrow. A dose only 2-3 times the 'effective' dose can cause fatal hyperthermia (body temperature >40 degrees C), profuse sweating, tachycardia, and death. There is no antidote. DNP was banned in 1938 by the FDA. It does NOT block absorption (A), directly burn fat chemically (C), or increase appetite (D).

questions.question: Succinate dehydrogenase (Complex II) catalyzes the oxidation of succinate to fumarate in the TCA cycle. This reaction involves what type of chemical transformation?
options: A decarboxylation reaction releasing CO2
A phosphorylation reaction using GTP

A trans-dehydrogenation removing two hydrogen atoms from adjacent carbons to form a trans double bond (C=C) — the enzyme contains a covalently bound FAD that accepts a hydride equivalent; the electrons then pass through three Fe-S clusters to ubiquinone
A hydrolysis reaction adding water across a bond
questions.explanation: Succinate dehydrogenase catalyzes the stereospecific oxidation of succinate to fumarate: succinate + FAD → fumarate + FADH2. This is a trans-elimination (dehydrogenation) that removes two hydrogen atoms from the C2 and C3 carbons of succinate, creating the trans (E) double bond of fumarate. The reaction is stereospecific — only the trans isomer is produced (fumarate), not the cis isomer (maleate). The enzyme uses FAD rather than NAD+ as the electron acceptor because the succinate/fumarate half-reaction (E'0 = +30 mV) is not sufficiently exergonic to reduce NAD+ (E'0 = -320 mV), but can reduce FAD (E'0 approximately -220 mV, though when covalently bound in SDH, the effective potential is modified). FAD is covalently linked to a histidine residue of the SDHA subunit. After FAD accepts the hydride, electrons pass through three Fe-S clusters ([2Fe-2S], [4Fe-4S], [3Fe-4S]) to the ubiquinone-binding site, where they reduce Q to QH2. This is NOT a decarboxylation (A) — no CO2 is released. It is NOT hydrolysis (C) — the next reaction (fumarase) adds water. It is NOT phosphorylation (D).

questions.question: The complete oxidation of one molecule of palmitate (C16 fatty acid) by beta-oxidation and subsequent TCA cycle/ETC processing yields approximately how many ATP equivalents?
options: Approximately 200 ATP because fat is the most energy-dense macronutrient

Approximately 106 ATP — palmitate undergoes 7 rounds of beta-oxidation yielding 8 acetyl-CoA, 7 FADH2, and 7 NADH; each acetyl-CoA generates approximately 10 ATP through the TCA cycle and ETC (3 NADH x 2.5 + 1 FADH2 x 1.5 + 1 GTP = 10); subtracting 2 ATP equivalents for initial activation (palmitoyl-CoA formation) gives 80 + 10.5 + 17.5 - 2 = 106 ATP
Approximately 10 ATP because beta-oxidation is an inefficient pathway
Approximately 38 ATP, the same as glucose oxidation
