questions.explanation: Palmitate (C16:0) is the most common saturated fatty acid. Its complete oxidation proceeds: ACTIVATION: Palmitate + CoA + ATP → Palmitoyl-CoA + AMP + PPi. This costs 2 ATP equivalents (ATP → AMP, equivalent to 2 ATP → 2 ADP). BETA-OXIDATION (7 rounds for C16): Each round removes 2 carbons as acetyl-CoA and produces 1 FADH2 and 1 NADH. 7 rounds yield: 8 acetyl-CoA + 7 FADH2 + 7 NADH. TCA CYCLE (8 acetyl-CoA): Each acetyl-CoA → 3 NADH + 1 FADH2 + 1 GTP. 8 x (3 NADH + 1 FADH2 + 1 GTP) = 24 NADH + 8 FADH2 + 8 GTP. TOTAL REDUCING EQUIVALENTS: NADH: 7 + 24 = 31 NADH → 31 x 2.5 = 77.5 ATP. FADH2: 7 + 8 = 15 FADH2 → 15 x 1.5 = 22.5 ATP. GTP: 8 → 8 ATP. TOTAL: 77.5 + 22.5 + 8 = 108 ATP. Minus 2 ATP for activation = 106 NET ATP. This high ATP yield (106 versus approximately 30-32 from glucose) explains why fat is the most energy-dense macronutrient (9 kcal/g versus 4 kcal/g for carbohydrates) and why fat is the preferred storage form of metabolic energy.

questions.question: In gluconeogenesis, the enzyme fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase (FBPase-1) catalyzes the hydrolysis of fructose-1,6-bisphosphate to fructose-6-phosphate. Which metabolite is the most potent inhibitor of this enzyme?
options: ATP is the strongest inhibitor because high energy charge should inhibit glucose production
Citrate inhibits FBPase-1 to prevent gluconeogenesis when TCA intermediates are abundant

Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate (F-2,6-BP) is the most potent inhibitor of FBPase-1, just as it is the most potent activator of PFK-1 — this reciprocal regulation ensures that glycolysis and gluconeogenesis are coordinately and inversely controlled
FBPase-1 is not regulated and operates constitutively
questions.explanation: Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate (F-2,6-BP) serves as the master regulatory metabolite for the reciprocal regulation of glycolysis and gluconeogenesis at the PFK-1/FBPase-1 node. F-2,6-BP activates PFK-1 (glycolysis) AND inhibits FBPase-1 (gluconeogenesis) — ensuring that only one direction operates at a time. This dual regulation prevents a futile cycle (F-6-P → F-1,6-BP → F-6-P) that would waste ATP. The levels of F-2,6-BP are controlled by the bifunctional enzyme PFK-2/FBPase-2: In the FED state (insulin signaling): PFK-2/FBPase-2 is dephosphorylated → PFK-2 kinase activity dominates → F-2,6-BP rises → glycolysis stimulated, gluconeogenesis inhibited. In the FASTING state (glucagon signaling): PKA phosphorylates PFK-2/FBPase-2 → FBPase-2 phosphatase activity dominates → F-2,6-BP falls → glycolysis slows, gluconeogenesis activated. AMP also inhibits FBPase-1 (but AMP signals low energy, when gluconeogenesis should indeed be inhibited to save ATP). ATP does NOT inhibit FBPase-1 (B) — high ATP actually favors gluconeogenesis because the pathway requires ATP. Citrate activates FBPase-1, not inhibits it (C). FBPase-1 IS tightly regulated (D).

questions.question: Superoxide dismutase (SOD) is a critical antioxidant enzyme in mitochondria. Which form of SOD is specifically localized to the mitochondrial matrix, and what reaction does it catalyze?
options: SOD1 (Cu/Zn-SOD) is the mitochondrial form that converts superoxide to hydrogen gas

SOD2 (Mn-SOD) is the mitochondrial matrix form that catalyzes: 2 O2.- + 2 H+ → H2O2 + O2, converting the highly reactive superoxide radical to less reactive hydrogen peroxide; H2O2 is then detoxified by glutathione peroxidase or catalase
SOD3 (extracellular SOD) provides all the mitochondrial antioxidant defense
There is no SOD in mitochondria; all ROS detoxification occurs in the cytoplasm
questions.explanation: Three isoforms of superoxide dismutase exist in mammals, each in a specific compartment: SOD1 (Cu/Zn-SOD): Cytoplasm and mitochondrial intermembrane space. SOD2 (Mn-SOD): Mitochondrial matrix — the primary defense against superoxide generated by the ETC. SOD3 (EC-SOD): Extracellular. SOD2 contains manganese at its active site and catalyzes the disproportionation (dismutation) of superoxide: 2 O2.- + 2 H+ → H2O2 + O2. This converts the highly reactive superoxide radical (which can damage Fe-S clusters, DNA, and lipids) to hydrogen peroxide (less reactive but still potentially harmful). H2O2 is subsequently detoxified by: (1) Glutathione peroxidase (GPx): H2O2 + 2 GSH → 2 H2O + GSSG, using the reducing power of glutathione. GSSG is recycled to GSH by glutathione reductase using NADPH. (2) Catalase (primarily in peroxisomes): 2 H2O2 → 2 H2O + O2. (3) Peroxiredoxins. SOD2 knockout mice die within weeks of birth from severe oxidative damage, demonstrating the essential role of mitochondrial antioxidant defense. SOD1 is cytoplasmic, not the mitochondrial matrix form (A). Mitochondria DO contain SOD (C). SOD3 is extracellular (D).

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about the regulation of pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDC):
S1: PDC is inactivated by phosphorylation (by PDH kinase) and reactivated by dephosphorylation (by PDH phosphatase)
S2: PDH kinase is activated by high ratios of acetyl-CoA/CoA, NADH/NAD+, and ATP/ADP, reflecting energy sufficiency
S3: Calcium ions activate PDH phosphatase, linking PDC activity to muscle contraction and hormonal signaling
S4: PDC regulation is exclusively controlled by allosteric effectors with no covalent modification
options: TTTF
TTTT
TTFT
TFTF
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE: PDC is regulated by a phosphorylation/dephosphorylation cycle on three serine residues of the E1-alpha subunit (Ser-264 is the primary site). PDH kinase (PDK, 4 isoforms PDK1-4) phosphorylates and INACTIVATES PDC. PDH phosphatase (PDP, 2 isoforms PDP1-2) dephosphorylates and REACTIVATES PDC. This is a classic example of interconvertible enzyme regulation. S2 is TRUE: PDH kinase activity is stimulated by the products of the PDC reaction and indicators of energy sufficiency: high acetyl-CoA/CoA ratio (product accumulation), high NADH/NAD+ ratio (excess reducing equivalents), and high ATP/ADP ratio (energy sufficiency). When these ratios are high, PDK is activated, phosphorylates PDC, and slows pyruvate oxidation. Conversely, when these ratios are low (energy depletion), PDK is inhibited, PDC remains dephosphorylated and active. Pyruvate itself also inhibits PDK, ensuring PDC activity when substrate is abundant. S3 is TRUE: Ca2+ directly activates PDP1 (PDH phosphatase 1) by binding to a specific site on the enzyme. During muscle contraction, cytoplasmic (and mitochondrial) Ca2+ levels rise, activating PDP1, which dephosphorylates and activates PDC, increasing acetyl-CoA production for the TCA cycle to meet increased energy demands. Insulin signaling also activates PDP through a separate mechanism. S4 is FALSE: PDC IS regulated by covalent modification (phosphorylation/dephosphorylation), as described in S1-S3. While it is also regulated allosterically by substrates and products, covalent modification is the primary regulatory mechanism.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about mitochondrial structure and function:
S1: The inner mitochondrial membrane is folded into cristae, which greatly increase the surface area available for the electron transport chain and ATP synthase
S2: The mitochondrial matrix contains the enzymes of the TCA cycle, pyruvate dehydrogenase, and beta-oxidation, as well as mitochondrial DNA, ribosomes, and tRNAs
S3: The outer mitochondrial membrane is freely permeable to all molecules up to approximately 5000 Da due to porins (VDAC)
S4: Mitochondria replicate by binary fission independently of the cell cycle and are inherited exclusively from the paternal parent in mammals
options: TTTF
TTTT
TTFF
TFTT
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE: Cristae are invaginations of the inner mitochondrial membrane that dramatically increase the surface area (by approximately 5-10 fold) for oxidative phosphorylation. The ETC complexes and ATP synthase are embedded in the cristae membrane. Cristae morphology is dynamic and regulated — cells with high energy demand (cardiac muscle, neurons) have densely packed lamellar cristae, while cells with lower demand have fewer, tubular cristae. Cristae junctions (narrow openings where cristae connect to the inner boundary membrane) create distinct microcompartments within the IMS that concentrate protons near ATP synthase. S2 is TRUE: The mitochondrial matrix is a gel-like compartment containing: TCA cycle enzymes (all soluble except SDH), pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, beta-oxidation enzymes, amino acid catabolism enzymes, and the machinery for mitochondrial gene expression — mtDNA (circular, approximately 16.5 kb in humans), mitochondrial ribosomes (55S, smaller than cytoplasmic 80S), tRNAs, and aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases. S3 is TRUE: The outer mitochondrial membrane contains voltage-dependent anion channels (VDAC, also called mitochondrial porins) — large beta-barrel channels that allow free passage of molecules up to approximately 5000 Da, including ions, metabolites (ATP, ADP, pyruvate, fatty acyl-CoA), and small proteins. This makes the intermembrane space composition similar to the cytosol for small molecules. S4 is FALSE in two respects: While mitochondria do divide by fission (involving dynamin-related GTPases like Drp1), this process is coordinated with the cell cycle and cellular energy demands, not completely independent. More critically, in mammals, mitochondria are inherited almost exclusively from the MATERNAL parent (through the egg cytoplasm), not paternal. Paternal mitochondria from sperm are tagged with ubiquitin and degraded by autophagy after fertilization.

questions.question:
A student measures the ATP yield from the complete oxidation of glucose using the following accounting:

Stage | NADH produced | FADH2 produced | ATP (substrate level)
Glycolysis | 2 | 0 | 2
Pyruvate oxidation | 2 | 0 | 0
TCA cycle (2 turns) | 6 | 2 | 2

Using P/O ratios of 2.5 for NADH and 1.5 for FADH2, calculate the maximum theoretical ATP yield. The student's textbook states 36-38 ATP. Explain the discrepancy.
options: The maximum yield is exactly 38 ATP with no discrepancy — the textbook is correct using older P/O ratios of 3 and 2

Total NADH: 10, producing 10 x 2.5 = 25 ATP; FADH2: 2, producing 2 x 1.5 = 3 ATP; substrate-level: 4 ATP; TOTAL = 32 ATP maximum — the lower value compared to the textbook's 36-38 reflects updated non-integer P/O ratios (2.5 and 1.5 instead of the older 3 and 2), plus the fact that the 2 cytoplasmic NADH from glycolysis may yield only 1.5 ATP each (via glycerol-3-phosphate shuttle) instead of 2.5 (via malate-aspartate shuttle), giving a range of 30-32 ATP
The yield is exactly 100 ATP because the calculation must include heat energy
ATP yield cannot be calculated because it depends entirely on oxygen concentration
questions.explanation: Detailed ATP accounting for complete glucose oxidation: MITOCHONDRIAL NADH (produced inside matrix): Pyruvate oxidation: 2 NADH → 2 x 2.5 = 5.0 ATP. TCA cycle: 6 NADH → 6 x 2.5 = 15.0 ATP. Subtotal: 20.0 ATP from 8 matrix NADH. CYTOPLASMIC NADH (from glycolysis, must be shuttled): 2 NADH — yield depends on which shuttle system is used: Via malate-aspartate shuttle (liver, heart): Matrix NADH regenerated → 2 x 2.5 = 5.0 ATP. Via glycerol-3-phosphate shuttle (muscle, brain): Electrons enter at ubiquinone level → 2 x 1.5 = 3.0 ATP. FADH2: 2 FADH2 (TCA cycle, at SDH) → 2 x 1.5 = 3.0 ATP. SUBSTRATE-LEVEL PHOSPHORYLATION: Glycolysis: 2 ATP. TCA cycle: 2 GTP (= 2 ATP). Total: 4 ATP. GRAND TOTAL: With malate-aspartate shuttle: 20 + 5 + 3 + 4 = 32 ATP. With glycerol-3-phosphate shuttle: 20 + 3 + 3 + 4 = 30 ATP. Hence the modern range of 30-32 ATP per glucose. The older textbook values of 36-38 used P/O ratios of 3.0 (NADH) and 2.0 (FADH2), which were overestimates. The updated non-integer ratios (2.5 and 1.5) reflect the stoichiometry of 10 H+ per NADH, 6 H+ per FADH2, and approximately 4 H+ per ATP (including transport costs).

questions.question:
Researchers study the effect of various ETC inhibitors and uncouplers on isolated mitochondria, measuring both oxygen consumption rate (OCR) and ATP production rate:

Condition | OCR (relative) | ATP production (relative)
Control (substrate + ADP) | 100 | 100
+ Rotenone (Complex I inhibitor) | 5 | 5
+ Rotenone + Succinate | 60 | 55
+ Antimycin A | 3 | 2
+ FCCP (uncoupler) | 150 | 10
+ Oligomycin | 15 | 3
+ Oligomycin + FCCP | 145 | 5

What do the results with oligomycin followed by FCCP reveal about the relationship between electron transport and ATP synthesis?
options: The results show that electron transport and ATP synthesis are completely independent processes

Oligomycin alone inhibits both OCR (to 15%) and ATP (to 3%) because blocking proton return through ATP synthase builds up pmf that opposes further proton pumping by the ETC; adding FCCP after oligomycin restores OCR to 145% (near uncoupled maximum) while ATP remains low (5%), demonstrating that the ETC is FULLY FUNCTIONAL but was being restrained by the high pmf — this proves that electron transport and ATP synthesis are coupled through the proton gradient, not through a direct chemical or conformational linkage
Oligomycin plus FCCP produces maximum ATP, showing they work synergistically
The data are inconsistent and do not support any conclusion about coupling
questions.explanation: This classic experiment demonstrates the chemiosmotic coupling mechanism: OLIGOMYCIN ALONE: Blocks the Fo proton channel of ATP synthase. Protons cannot flow back to the matrix, so the pmf increases. As pmf rises, the ETC complexes face an increasingly unfavorable thermodynamic gradient for proton pumping, so electron transport slows dramatically (OCR drops to 15%). ATP production essentially stops (3%). This shows electron transport IS coupled to ATP synthesis — but through what mechanism? OLIGOMYCIN + FCCP: FCCP provides an alternative path for proton return (bypassing the blocked ATP synthase). The pmf is dissipated, removing the thermodynamic back-pressure on the ETC. Electron transport races at maximum uncoupled rate (OCR = 145%), proving the ETC components are fully functional — they were merely being held back by the high pmf. However, ATP production remains negligible (5%) because: (1) ATP synthase is still blocked by oligomycin. (2) The pmf is dissipated by FCCP, so even if some proton channels were open, there is no gradient to drive ATP synthesis. KEY INSIGHT: The ETC and ATP synthase are coupled ONLY through the proton gradient. They share no direct chemical or conformational linkage. This is the essence of Mitchell's chemiosmotic hypothesis. Option A is wrong — they ARE coupled (through the pmf). Option C reverses the actual result. The data are entirely consistent (D).

questions.question: A researcher wants to measure the contribution of Complex I versus Complex II to total mitochondrial respiration in a tissue sample. Which experimental design using isolated mitochondria would accomplish this?
options: Measure total cellular ATP levels with and without glucose

Use substrate-specific respiration measurements: (1) Add glutamate/malate (Complex I substrates that generate matrix NADH) and measure OCR — this represents Complex I-driven respiration; (2) Add rotenone to block Complex I, then add succinate (Complex II substrate) and measure OCR — this represents Complex II-driven respiration; (3) Compare the rates to determine relative contributions; validate by showing that antimycin A blocks both
Sequence the mitochondrial genome to identify mutations
Measure the total protein content of mitochondrial extracts
questions.explanation: This experimental design exploits the substrate specificity of ETC entry points to separately measure Complex I and Complex II contributions. COMPLEX I MEASUREMENT: Glutamate/malate are metabolized in the matrix to produce NADH (glutamate dehydrogenase: glutamate → alpha-ketoglutarate + NADH; malate dehydrogenase: malate → oxaloacetate + NADH). This NADH enters the ETC exclusively at Complex I. The resulting OCR represents Complex I-driven respiration. Adding ADP (State 3) gives the coupled Complex I respiration rate. COMPLEX II MEASUREMENT: First, rotenone is added to completely block Complex I (preventing any NADH-derived electron flow). Then succinate is added — it is oxidized by succinate dehydrogenase (Complex II), which transfers electrons directly to ubiquinone via FADH2 and Fe-S clusters, bypassing Complex I entirely. The OCR measured with rotenone + succinate represents Complex II-driven respiration. VALIDATION: Adding antimycin A (Complex III inhibitor) should block both Complex I and Complex II-driven respiration, confirming that both pathways converge at ubiquinone → Complex III → Complex IV. This approach is widely used in clinical mitochondrial diagnostics (e.g., using Seahorse XF Analyzer). ATP levels alone (A) cannot distinguish complex contributions. Genomic sequencing (C) and protein content (D) are not functional measurements.

questions.question: What is the role of coenzyme Q (ubiquinone) in the electron transport chain?
options: It is a protein-bound cofactor that remains fixed within Complex III
It serves as the terminal electron acceptor of the ETC, replacing oxygen

It is a small, lipid-soluble electron carrier that shuttles electrons from Complexes I and II to Complex III — it can accept one electron (forming semiquinone, QH.) or two electrons (forming ubiquinol, QH2), and its mobility within the lipid bilayer allows it to collect electrons from multiple sources and deliver them to a single recipient
It transfers electrons from Complex IV to oxygen
questions.explanation: Ubiquinone (coenzyme Q, CoQ10 in humans) is a small, hydrophobic molecule consisting of a benzoquinone ring attached to an isoprenoid tail (10 isoprene units in humans). Its lipid solubility allows it to diffuse freely within the inner mitochondrial membrane's lipid bilayer. CoQ serves as a mobile electron carrier that collects electrons from multiple dehydrogenases: Complex I (NADH dehydrogenase), Complex II (succinate dehydrogenase), electron-transferring flavoprotein (ETF) dehydrogenase (from fatty acid beta-oxidation FADH2), and glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase. It delivers all these electrons to Complex III (cytochrome bc1). CoQ can exist in three redox states: fully oxidized (ubiquinone, Q), one-electron-reduced (semiquinone, QH.), and fully reduced (ubiquinol, QH2). The two-electron reduction picks up 2 H+ from the matrix side of the membrane. The Q pool acts as a buffer, maintaining a dynamic equilibrium between Q, QH., and QH2. CoQ does NOT transfer electrons to Complex IV (A) — cytochrome c does that. CoQ is freely mobile, not fixed (C). Oxygen, not CoQ, is the terminal acceptor (D).

questions.question: During the TCA cycle, the conversion of succinyl-CoA to succinate is coupled to GTP (or ATP) synthesis. What type of phosphorylation is this, and what provides the driving force?
options: This is photophosphorylation powered by light energy

This is substrate-level phosphorylation — the energy-rich thioester bond of succinyl-CoA (delta-G-zero-prime of hydrolysis approximately -33.5 kJ/mol) drives the phosphorylation of GDP to GTP; the reaction proceeds through a phosphohistidine enzyme intermediate
This is oxidative phosphorylation driven by the proton gradient
This is a kinase reaction that requires an external ATP source
questions.explanation: Succinyl-CoA synthetase (also called succinate thiokinase) catalyzes the only substrate-level phosphorylation in the TCA cycle: succinyl-CoA + Pi + GDP → succinate + CoA + GTP. The mechanism proceeds in three steps: (1) The thioester bond of succinyl-CoA is cleaved, with the released energy used to form a succinyl-phosphate intermediate (high-energy mixed anhydride between succinate and phosphate). (2) The phosphoryl group is transferred from succinyl-phosphate to a histidine residue on the enzyme, forming a phosphohistidine intermediate. (3) The phosphoryl group is transferred from phosphohistidine to GDP, forming GTP. The driving force is the hydrolysis of the thioester bond of succinyl-CoA, which has a large negative delta-G-zero-prime (approximately -33.5 kJ/mol) — sufficient to drive phosphorylation of GDP (requiring approximately +30.5 kJ/mol). In animals, two isoforms exist: GTP-forming (in liver and other tissues) and ATP-forming (in some tissues). The GTP produced can be converted to ATP by nucleoside diphosphate kinase (GTP + ADP → GDP + ATP). This is NOT oxidative phosphorylation (B), does not require external ATP (C), and has nothing to do with light (D).

questions.question: Cytochrome c is a small (approximately 12 kDa) mobile electron carrier in the intermembrane space. What structural feature allows it to shuttle electrons between Complex III and Complex IV?
options: Cytochrome c is an integral membrane protein that spans the inner membrane multiple times

Cytochrome c contains a heme c prosthetic group with an iron atom that alternates between Fe2+ (reduced, ferrous) and Fe3+ (oxidized, ferric) states — the heme is covalently attached to the protein via two thioether bonds to cysteine residues, and the protein's small size and positive surface charge allow it to diffuse along the outer face of the inner membrane between Complexes III and IV
Cytochrome c contains a copper center that alternates between Cu+ and Cu2+
Cytochrome c transfers electrons by physically detaching from one complex, diffusing through the matrix, and attaching to the next
questions.explanation: Cytochrome c is a small, globular, water-soluble protein that functions as a one-electron carrier in the intermembrane space. Key structural features: (1) HEME C: Unlike other cytochromes, heme c is covalently attached to the protein via two thioether bonds between the heme vinyl groups and Cys-14 and Cys-17 residues (consensus sequence Cys-X-X-Cys-His). The iron atom cycles between Fe2+ (reduced) and Fe3+ (oxidized) during electron transfer. (2) SIZE: At approximately 12 kDa and 104 amino acids, it is small enough to diffuse rapidly in the confined IMS space. (3) SURFACE CHARGE: The protein has a ring of positively charged lysine residues around the heme crevice that interact electrostatically with complementary negative patches on Complex III (cytochrome c1 subunit) and Complex IV (CuA subunit). These electrostatic interactions facilitate proper docking and electron transfer. Cytochrome c does NOT contain copper (A) — that is found in Complex IV (CuA, CuB). It is NOT an integral membrane protein (C) — it is a peripheral IMS protein that associates with the outer face of the inner membrane. It operates in the IMS, not the matrix (D).

questions.question: Hexokinase I (found in most tissues) is strongly inhibited by its product, glucose-6-phosphate. What is the physiological significance of this product inhibition?
options: Product inhibition ensures that hexokinase I always operates at maximum velocity
G6P inhibition of hexokinase I accelerates glycolysis by channeling more substrate through the pathway
Product inhibition has no physiological role; it is merely a kinetic artifact observed in vitro

When downstream metabolic pathways (glycolysis, PPP, glycogen synthesis) are saturated and G6P accumulates, hexokinase I is inhibited — this prevents unnecessary glucose phosphorylation that would deplete cellular ATP and trap phosphate groups, effectively coordinating glucose entry into metabolism with the cell's capacity to process it
questions.explanation: Hexokinase I product inhibition by glucose-6-phosphate (G6P) is a fundamental regulatory mechanism that coordinates glucose phosphorylation with metabolic demand. When downstream pathways are active and consuming G6P rapidly, [G6P] remains low and hexokinase operates freely. When downstream pathways slow down (glycolysis is inhibited by high ATP/citrate; PPP flux is limited by NADPH demand; glycogen stores are full), G6P accumulates and inhibits hexokinase I at physiological concentrations (Ki approximately 0.04 mM, well within the normal intracellular [G6P] range of 0.05-0.2 mM). This prevents: (1) WASTEFUL ATP CONSUMPTION — each glucose phosphorylation consumes 1 ATP. If hexokinase were unregulated, it would consume ATP without productive metabolism. (2) PHOSPHATE SEQUESTRATION — trapping Pi as organic phosphate esters would deplete the cell's inorganic phosphate pool, affecting all phosphate-requiring reactions. (3) OSMOTIC STRESS — accumulation of G6P (a charged molecule that cannot cross the membrane) would increase intracellular osmolarity. Notably, glucokinase (hexokinase IV in liver) is NOT inhibited by G6P, allowing the liver to continue phosphorylating glucose after meals regardless of [G6P]. Product inhibition IS physiologically important (A). It limits, not maximizes, velocity (C). It slows glucose entry, not accelerates it (D).

questions.question: Acetyl-CoA can enter the TCA cycle for complete oxidation, or it can be diverted to other metabolic pathways. Which of the following is NOT a metabolic fate of acetyl-CoA?
options: Direct conversion to glucose via gluconeogenesis (net synthesis of glucose from acetyl-CoA in animal cells)
Cholesterol and steroid hormone synthesis (via the mevalonate pathway in the cytoplasm)
Fatty acid synthesis (via export as citrate through the citrate shuttle)
Ketone body synthesis (acetoacetate, beta-hydroxybutyrate, acetone) in liver mitochondria during fasting or diabetes
questions.explanation: Acetyl-CoA is a central metabolic hub with multiple fates: (A) FATTY ACID SYNTHESIS — correct fate. Mitochondrial acetyl-CoA is exported to the cytoplasm as citrate (citrate + ATP + CoA → acetyl-CoA + oxaloacetate, catalyzed by ATP-citrate lyase). Cytoplasmic acetyl-CoA is then carboxylated to malonyl-CoA (by ACC) and used for fatty acid synthesis. (B) KETOGENESIS — correct fate. During fasting or uncontrolled diabetes, excess hepatic acetyl-CoA (from beta-oxidation, when OAA is diverted to gluconeogenesis) is converted to ketone bodies: 2 acetyl-CoA → acetoacetyl-CoA → HMG-CoA → acetoacetate → beta-hydroxybutyrate (or spontaneous decarboxylation to acetone). Ketone bodies serve as fuel for brain, heart, and muscle. (C) CHOLESTEROL SYNTHESIS — correct fate. Acetyl-CoA → acetoacetyl-CoA → HMG-CoA → mevalonate (by HMG-CoA reductase, the rate-limiting step and statin target) → isopentenyl-PP → squalene → cholesterol → steroid hormones. (D) GLUCONEOGENESIS FROM ACETYL-CoA — this is NOT possible in animals. The pyruvate dehydrogenase reaction is irreversible, and the two carbons of acetyl-CoA entering the TCA cycle are lost as 2 CO2 before OAA is regenerated. There is no net conversion of acetyl-CoA to glucose. This is why fat CANNOT be converted to glucose in animals (though glycerol from fat can).

questions.question: Metformin, the most widely prescribed diabetes drug, exerts its metabolic effects partly through Complex I inhibition. How does mild Complex I inhibition lead to improved glucose homeostasis?
options: Metformin directly stimulates insulin secretion from pancreatic beta cells

Mild Complex I inhibition reduces mitochondrial ATP production, increasing the AMP/ATP ratio, which activates AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) — AMPK then inhibits hepatic gluconeogenesis (reducing blood glucose), enhances glucose uptake in muscle, and stimulates fatty acid oxidation, collectively improving insulin sensitivity
Metformin blocks glucose absorption in the intestine by inhibiting Complex I in enterocytes
Complex I inhibition increases gluconeogenesis, which somehow lowers blood glucose through a paradoxical mechanism
questions.explanation: Metformin's mechanism of action involves multiple pathways, but a key component is mild Complex I inhibition in hepatocytes. At therapeutic concentrations, metformin accumulates in mitochondria (driven by the membrane potential) and mildly inhibits Complex I (NADH dehydrogenase). This reduces electron transport → reduces proton pumping → reduces ATP synthesis. The resulting decrease in ATP and increase in AMP activates AMPK, a master metabolic sensor kinase. AMPK activation produces multiple downstream effects: (1) INHIBITS HEPATIC GLUCONEOGENESIS: AMPK phosphorylates and inhibits key transcriptional coactivators (CRTC2, HDAC4) that drive expression of gluconeogenic enzymes (PEPCK, G6Pase), reducing glucose output by the liver. (2) ENHANCES GLUCOSE UPTAKE: AMPK promotes GLUT4 translocation to the plasma membrane in skeletal muscle, increasing glucose uptake. (3) STIMULATES FATTY ACID OXIDATION: AMPK phosphorylates and inhibits acetyl-CoA carboxylase (ACC), reducing malonyl-CoA levels, which relieves inhibition of CPT-I and promotes fatty acid beta-oxidation. (4) INHIBITS LIPOGENESIS: Reduced ACC activity also decreases fatty acid synthesis. Metformin does NOT stimulate insulin secretion (A) — that distinguishes it from sulfonylureas. It does NOT primarily work through intestinal absorption blockade (C). It INHIBITS, not increases, gluconeogenesis (D).

questions.question: Why does the conversion of pyruvate to lactate by lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) not involve any net change in the oxidation state of carbon?
options: Lactate and pyruvate have the same molecular formula with no difference in hydrogen content
The reaction occurs too quickly for any redox chemistry to take place

The reduction of pyruvate's keto group to a hydroxyl group (gaining 2 electrons) is exactly balanced by the oxidation of NADH to NAD+ (donating 2 electrons) — this is an intermolecular redox reaction where one molecule is reduced while the coenzyme is oxidized, with no net change in carbon oxidation when you consider only the carbon substrate's initial and final states relative to the overall pathway
Because LDH is not a redox enzyme and does not catalyze an oxidation-reduction reaction
questions.explanation: The LDH reaction (pyruvate + NADH + H+ → lactate + NAD+) IS a redox reaction — pyruvate is REDUCED to lactate (the C2 keto group is reduced to a hydroxyl), and NADH is OXIDIZED to NAD+. However, within the context of the overall fermentation pathway (glucose → 2 lactate), the net oxidation state of carbon does not change from glucose to lactate. In glucose, the average carbon oxidation state is 0 (C6H12O6). In lactate (C3H6O3), the average carbon oxidation state is also 0. This makes sense because fermentation involves no net oxidation — no external electron acceptor (like O2) is used. The NADH produced in glycolysis (at GAPDH) is consumed by LDH, so the NAD+/NADH balance is maintained internally. The LDH reaction specifically involves the transfer of a hydride from NADH to the C2 carbonyl of pyruvate, reducing it to a secondary alcohol. This is indeed a redox reaction (A is wrong). Lactate and pyruvate do NOT have the same formula — lactate has 2 more hydrogens (C is wrong). The speed of the reaction does not prevent redox chemistry (D).

questions.question: Mitochondrial diseases caused by mutations in mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) show maternal inheritance and heteroplasmy. What is heteroplasmy and why does it complicate diagnosis and phenotype prediction?
options: Heteroplasmy is a type of mitochondrial fusion that repairs damaged mtDNA
Heteroplasmy means all mitochondria in a cell carry the same mtDNA genotype

Heteroplasmy means a cell contains a mixture of normal and mutant mtDNA molecules — the phenotypic severity depends on the proportion of mutant mtDNA (threshold effect, typically >60-80% mutant for symptoms), which varies between cells and tissues due to random mitotic segregation during cell division, making disease expression highly variable even within the same family
Heteroplasmy refers to the nuclear DNA mutations that affect mitochondrial proteins
questions.explanation: Each human cell contains hundreds to thousands of mitochondria, each with 2-10 copies of the circular mtDNA (total approximately 1000-10000 copies per cell). Heteroplasmy refers to the coexistence of two or more different mtDNA genotypes (e.g., wild-type and mutant) within the same cell. Key implications: (1) THRESHOLD EFFECT: Mitochondrial function is maintained as long as the proportion of wild-type mtDNA exceeds a minimum threshold (typically 20-40% wild-type, or equivalently, symptoms appear when mutant mtDNA exceeds approximately 60-80%). Below this threshold, the wild-type copies produce enough functional ETC components to sustain adequate OXPHOS. (2) RANDOM MITOTIC SEGREGATION: During cell division, mitochondria (and their mtDNA) are distributed randomly to daughter cells. This means the proportion of mutant mtDNA can vary widely between cells, tissues, and even between family members inheriting the same mutation from their mother. (3) TISSUE-SPECIFIC EFFECTS: Tissues with high energy demands (brain, muscle, heart, retina) are most vulnerable to OXPHOS deficiency, explaining why mitochondrial diseases often present as encephalomyopathies, cardiomyopathies, and optic neuropathies. When all mtDNA copies are identical, it is called homoplasmy (A describes this). Nuclear DNA mutations are separate from mtDNA heteroplasmy (C). Heteroplasmy is not a repair mechanism (D).

questions.question: Aconitase catalyzes the reversible isomerization of citrate to isocitrate in the TCA cycle. Why must citrate first be converted to isocitrate before oxidative decarboxylation can occur?
options: The isomerization is required to remove water from the TCA cycle
Citrate already contains a hydroxyl group suitable for oxidation, so the isomerization is unnecessary

Citrate is a tertiary alcohol (the hydroxyl is on a carbon bonded to three other carbons including one carboxylate), which cannot be directly oxidized by NAD+-dependent dehydrogenases — aconitase moves the hydroxyl to the adjacent carbon, creating isocitrate (a secondary alcohol) that CAN be oxidized by isocitrate dehydrogenase
Aconitase only exists to regulate the TCA cycle by controlling the rate of isocitrate formation
questions.explanation: This is an elegant example of metabolic logic. Citrate has a hydroxyl group at C3, but this is a TERTIARY alcohol — the carbon bearing the -OH is bonded to three other carbons (including the carboxylate group). Tertiary alcohols cannot be directly oxidized by NAD+- or FAD-dependent dehydrogenases because the oxidation product would require forming a C=O bond on a carbon already bonded to three carbons, which is energetically and mechanistically unfavorable (no hydrogen to remove from the hydroxyl-bearing carbon). Aconitase solves this problem through a two-step dehydration-rehydration mechanism: (1) Removes water from citrate to form the intermediate cis-aconitate (with a C=C double bond). (2) Re-adds water to the opposite end of the double bond, placing the hydroxyl on C2 instead of C3. This creates ISOCITRATE, a SECONDARY alcohol (the hydroxyl-bearing carbon is bonded to only two other carbons). Isocitrate dehydrogenase can then oxidize the secondary alcohol to a ketone (oxalosuccinate intermediate), followed by decarboxylation to alpha-ketoglutarate. The aconitase reaction uses an [4Fe-4S] iron-sulfur cluster to coordinate the substrate and catalyze the stereospecific dehydration/rehydration. While citrate does have a hydroxyl (A), it cannot be oxidized in that position. The primary purpose is chemical feasibility, not regulation (C). Water balance is not the reason (D).

questions.question: What is the role of the adenylate kinase (myokinase) reaction in cellular energy homeostasis?
options: Adenylate kinase synthesizes AMP from adenine and ribose-5-phosphate
Adenylate kinase only functions in nucleotide biosynthesis and has no role in energy sensing
Adenylate kinase converts AMP to IMP as part of the purine salvage pathway

Adenylate kinase catalyzes: 2 ADP ↔ ATP + AMP — this reaction amplifies the energy signal because a small decrease in ATP (with corresponding ADP increase) generates AMP, which is a much more sensitive indicator of energy depletion and a potent activator of AMPK and PFK-1
questions.explanation: Adenylate kinase (also called myokinase in muscle) catalyzes the reversible reaction: 2 ADP ↔ ATP + AMP. This seemingly simple reaction has profound implications for metabolic regulation through SIGNAL AMPLIFICATION. Consider a cell with initial concentrations: [ATP] = 5 mM, [ADP] = 0.5 mM, [AMP] = 0.05 mM (adenylate energy charge = 0.95). If 10% of ATP is consumed: [ATP] drops from 5.0 to 4.5 mM (10% decrease), [ADP] rises from 0.5 to 1.0 mM (100% increase). The adenylate kinase equilibrium then converts some of this ADP to ATP + AMP, causing [AMP] to rise from 0.05 to approximately 0.3 mM (approximately 600% increase!). This amplification means that AMP concentration is an extremely sensitive indicator of energy status — a modest 10% decline in ATP produces a many-fold increase in AMP. AMP serves as a critical allosteric activator of: (1) PFK-1 (stimulating glycolysis), (2) AMPK (AMP-activated protein kinase, the master metabolic sensor), (3) Glycogen phosphorylase (stimulating glycogenolysis). AMP also allosterically inhibits fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase (blocking gluconeogenesis). The reaction does NOT synthesize AMP de novo (A). It plays a central role in energy sensing (C). Conversion of AMP to IMP is catalyzed by AMP deaminase, not adenylate kinase (D).

questions.question: Mitochondrial supercomplexes (respirasomes) are organized assemblies of ETC complexes. What is the proposed functional advantage of supercomplex formation?
options: Supercomplexes prevent the ETC from functioning and serve only a structural role
Supercomplexes function only in plant mitochondria, not in animal cells

Supercomplexes (typically I-III2-IV or I-III2) create dedicated electron transfer pathways that minimize the diffusion distance for mobile carriers (CoQ, cytochrome c), reduce electron leak to oxygen (decreasing ROS production), and increase the overall efficiency and rate of electron transport through substrate channeling
Supercomplexes are experimental artifacts that do not exist in intact mitochondria
questions.explanation: Mitochondrial supercomplexes (also called respirasomes) are stable associations of individual ETC complexes. The most common supercomplex in mammalian mitochondria is the respirasome: Complex I + Complex III dimer + Complex IV (I-III2-IV), though I-III2 is also abundant. Cryo-EM structures have confirmed their existence and organization. Proposed advantages: (1) SUBSTRATE CHANNELING: By positioning CoQ reduction (Complex I) and CoQ oxidation (Complex III) sites in close proximity, electrons are channeled through a dedicated CoQ pool trapped within the supercomplex rather than relying on diffusion through the bulk membrane CoQ pool. Similarly, cytochrome c may shuttle within a confined space between Complex III and IV. (2) REDUCED ROS PRODUCTION: Shorter electron transfer distances and channeled CoQ reduce the lifetime of reactive intermediates (especially semiquinone at the Qo site of Complex III), decreasing electron leak to O2. (3) INCREASED EFFICIENCY: Kinetic modeling and experimental data suggest that supercomplex organization increases overall electron transfer rates compared to randomly distributed complexes. (4) COMPLEX I STABILITY: Association with Complex III stabilizes Complex I, preventing its degradation. Supercomplexes are clearly functional (A). They have been confirmed by blue-native PAGE, cryo-EM, and crosslinking mass spectrometry (C). They exist in both animals and plants (D).

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about the energetics of electron transport:
S1: The standard reduction potential of the NAD+/NADH couple (-320 mV) is more negative than the O2/H2O couple (+816 mV), indicating that NADH is a strong reducing agent and electrons flow spontaneously from NADH to O2
S2: The free energy released by electron transport from NADH to O2 is captured entirely as heat with no useful work
S3: The electron transport chain is arranged in order of increasing reduction potential, ensuring thermodynamically favorable electron flow at each step
S4: Each ETC complex has a unique standard reduction potential that determines where it sits in the electron transfer sequence
options: TFTT
TTTT
TFTF
TFFT
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE: The more negative the standard reduction potential (E'0), the stronger the reducing agent (greater tendency to donate electrons). NADH (E'0 = -320 mV) has a strong tendency to donate electrons, while O2 (E'0 = +816 mV) has a strong tendency to accept electrons. Electrons flow spontaneously from lower to higher reduction potential: delta-E'0 = +816 - (-320) = +1136 mV, corresponding to delta-G'0 = -219 kJ/mol (highly exergonic). S2 is FALSE: The energy released during electron transport is NOT captured entirely as heat. Instead, it is used to pump protons across the inner mitochondrial membrane, creating the proton-motive force. This stored energy then drives ATP synthesis by ATP synthase. Approximately 34% of the energy is captured as ATP; the remainder is dissipated as heat (consistent with the second law of thermodynamics). S3 is TRUE: The ETC components are arranged in order of increasing (more positive) reduction potential: NADH (-320 mV) → FMN (-300 mV) → Fe-S clusters → CoQ (+45 mV) → cytochrome b (+77 mV) → cytochrome c1 (+215 mV) → cytochrome c (+254 mV) → CuA (+245 mV) → cytochrome a (+290 mV) → CuB/cytochrome a3 (+800 mV) → O2 (+816 mV). Each transfer is thermodynamically favorable (electron moves to a higher potential). S4 is TRUE: Each complex contains multiple redox centers with specific reduction potentials. These potentials determine the thermodynamic favorability and sequence of electron transfer within and between complexes.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about the regulation of the citric acid cycle:
S1: The three primary regulatory enzymes of the TCA cycle are citrate synthase, isocitrate dehydrogenase, and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
S2: All three regulatory enzymes catalyze reactions far from equilibrium (large negative delta-G) and are allosterically regulated
S3: The TCA cycle rate is primarily determined by the availability of NAD+, which is regenerated by the electron transport chain
S4: In muscle, increased Ca2+ during contraction activates only isocitrate dehydrogenase but not the other TCA cycle regulatory enzymes
options: TTTF
TTTT
TTFT
TFTT
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE: The three primary control points of the TCA cycle are: (1) Citrate synthase: acetyl-CoA + OAA → citrate. Regulated by substrate availability (OAA, acetyl-CoA) and product/allosteric inhibition (citrate, NADH, succinyl-CoA, ATP). (2) Isocitrate dehydrogenase (NAD+-dependent, IDH3): isocitrate → alpha-KG. Activated by ADP, Ca2+; inhibited by ATP, NADH. (3) Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase: alpha-KG → succinyl-CoA. Inhibited by succinyl-CoA, NADH; activated by Ca2+. S2 is TRUE: All three catalyze essentially irreversible reactions with large negative delta-G values under cellular conditions: citrate synthase (approximately -32 kJ/mol standard, even more negative in vivo), isocitrate dehydrogenase (approximately -21 kJ/mol), alpha-KGDH (approximately -33 kJ/mol). Their far-from-equilibrium status means their flux is determined by enzyme regulation (kinetic control), not mass action (thermodynamic control). Each is subject to allosteric regulation by indicators of energy status. S3 is TRUE: NAD+ availability is a critical determinant of TCA cycle rate because three of the eight cycle reactions require NAD+ as a substrate (isocitrate DH, alpha-KGDH, malate DH). NAD+ is regenerated by the ETC when it reoxidizes NADH. When the ETC is inhibited or saturated (all NAD+ converted to NADH), the TCA cycle cannot proceed. This creates tight coupling between the TCA cycle and oxidative phosphorylation. S4 is FALSE: Ca2+ activates ALL THREE regulatory enzymes — citrate synthase (indirectly, through increased OAA availability via isocitrate DH acceleration), isocitrate dehydrogenase (directly), and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase (directly). This coordinate activation by Ca2+ during muscle contraction increases TCA cycle flux to meet the elevated ATP demand.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about substrate-level phosphorylation vs oxidative phosphorylation:
S1: Substrate-level phosphorylation produces ATP directly by transfer of a phosphoryl group from a high-energy substrate to ADP
S2: Oxidative phosphorylation produces approximately 90% of the ATP generated during aerobic glucose oxidation
S3: Substrate-level phosphorylation requires oxygen, while oxidative phosphorylation does not
S4: Both substrate-level phosphorylation and oxidative phosphorylation occur in the mitochondria of eukaryotic cells
options: TTFF
TTFT
TFFT
TFTF
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE: Substrate-level phosphorylation involves direct transfer of a phosphoryl group from a phosphorylated substrate (with higher phosphoryl transfer potential than ATP) to ADP. Examples: (1) 1,3-BPG + ADP → 3-PG + ATP (phosphoglycerate kinase in glycolysis). (2) PEP + ADP → pyruvate + ATP (pyruvate kinase in glycolysis). (3) Succinyl-CoA + GDP + Pi → succinate + GTP (succinyl-CoA synthetase in TCA cycle). No electron transport chain or proton gradient is required. S2 is TRUE: Of the approximately 30-32 ATP produced per glucose: substrate-level phosphorylation produces 4 ATP (2 from glycolysis + 2 GTP from TCA cycle) = approximately 12.5% of total. Oxidative phosphorylation produces approximately 26-28 ATP (from 10 NADH x 2.5 + 2 FADH2 x 1.5 = 28 ATP, minus some for shuttle costs) = approximately 87.5% of total. So oxidative phosphorylation accounts for approximately 90% of total ATP. S3 is FALSE: This is REVERSED. Substrate-level phosphorylation does NOT require oxygen — it occurs in both glycolysis (cytoplasm, anaerobic) and the TCA cycle (matrix). Oxidative phosphorylation DOES require oxygen as the terminal electron acceptor at Complex IV. S4 is FALSE: Substrate-level phosphorylation occurs both in the cytoplasm (glycolysis: 2 ATP) and in the mitochondrial matrix (TCA cycle: 2 GTP). Oxidative phosphorylation occurs exclusively in mitochondria (at the inner membrane). The statement implies both occur only in mitochondria, which is incorrect for substrate-level phosphorylation.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about the pentose phosphate pathway (PPP) and its connection to cellular respiration:
S1: The PPP produces NADPH (for reductive biosynthesis and antioxidant defense) and ribose-5-phosphate (for nucleotide synthesis)
S2: The oxidative branch of the PPP is irreversible and regulated by glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase, which is inhibited by NADPH
S3: The non-oxidative branch of the PPP can interchange 3-, 4-, 5-, 6-, and 7-carbon sugar phosphates, connecting the PPP to glycolysis
S4: The PPP and glycolysis cannot operate simultaneously in the same cell
options: TTTF
TTTT
TFTF
TTFF
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE: The pentose phosphate pathway (also called hexose monophosphate shunt or phosphogluconate pathway) has two major products: (1) NADPH — produced in the oxidative branch (2 NADPH per glucose-6-phosphate, at glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase and 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase). NADPH is essential for reductive biosynthesis (fatty acid synthesis, cholesterol synthesis, amino acid synthesis), glutathione reduction (GSH maintenance for ROS detoxification), and NADPH oxidase (phagocyte respiratory burst). (2) Ribose-5-phosphate — the sugar backbone for nucleotide synthesis (DNA, RNA, ATP, CoA, NAD+, FAD). S2 is TRUE: The oxidative branch (glucose-6-phosphate → 6-phosphogluconate → ribulose-5-phosphate + 2 CO2 + 2 NADPH) is irreversible and tightly regulated. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PDH), the committed step enzyme, is allosterically inhibited by NADPH (product feedback). When NADPH/NADP+ ratio is high (biosynthetic demand met), the oxidative PPP slows. When NADPH is consumed (e.g., active fatty acid synthesis or oxidative stress), NADP+ accumulates and G6PDH is activated. G6PDH deficiency is the most common human enzyme deficiency, causing hemolytic anemia upon oxidative stress. S3 is TRUE: The non-oxidative branch contains transketolase and transaldolase, which catalyze reversible reactions interconverting sugar phosphates of different chain lengths (C3-C7). This allows ribulose-5-phosphate to be converted to glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate and fructose-6-phosphate (glycolytic intermediates), connecting the PPP to glycolysis. S4 is FALSE: The PPP and glycolysis operate simultaneously and are interconnected through shared intermediates (G6P, F6P, GAP). The relative flux through each pathway is determined by the cell's specific needs for ATP, NADPH, and ribose-5-phosphate.

questions.question:
A clinical laboratory measures blood lactate levels in a patient with a suspected mitochondrial myopathy:

Condition | Blood lactate (mmol/L) | Reference range
Fasting (resting) | 4.8 | 0.5-1.5
After mild exercise (10 min walking) | 8.5 | 1.0-2.5
After moderate exercise (10 min cycling) | 15.2 | 2.0-5.0
Recovery (30 min post-exercise) | 9.5 | 0.5-2.0

What do these results suggest about the patient's metabolic defect?
options: The results are normal and indicate no metabolic abnormality

Elevated baseline and exercise-induced lactate with delayed recovery strongly suggests impaired oxidative phosphorylation — the patient's mitochondria cannot adequately oxidize NADH via the ETC, forcing increased reliance on anaerobic glycolysis (lactate production to regenerate NAD+); the disproportionate lactate rise with exercise reflects the inability to meet increased ATP demand aerobically, and delayed recovery indicates impaired lactate clearance due to the mitochondrial defect in liver and muscle
The results indicate a deficiency in the enzyme lactate dehydrogenase
The high lactate levels are caused by dehydration, not a metabolic defect
questions.explanation: The laboratory findings are classic for mitochondrial myopathy: (1) ELEVATED RESTING LACTATE (4.8 mmol/L vs. reference 0.5-1.5): Even at rest, the patient cannot generate sufficient ATP via oxidative phosphorylation, forcing compensatory glycolysis. The excess pyruvate is converted to lactate by LDH to regenerate NAD+. (2) EXAGGERATED EXERCISE RESPONSE: Mild exercise causes lactate to rise to 8.5 (vs. normal <2.5), and moderate exercise to 15.2 (vs. normal <5.0). During exercise, ATP demand increases dramatically. Normal individuals meet this demand primarily through increased oxidative phosphorylation. This patient's impaired ETC/OXPHOS forces even greater reliance on anaerobic glycolysis, producing proportionally more lactate. (3) DELAYED RECOVERY: 30 minutes after exercise, lactate remains at 9.5 (vs. normal <2.0). Lactate clearance occurs primarily through: (a) hepatic gluconeogenesis (Cori cycle), and (b) oxidation to pyruvate and then acetyl-CoA in muscle and heart. Both pathways require functional mitochondria, so the mitochondrial defect impairs recovery as well. The lactate/pyruvate ratio is typically elevated (>20, normal approximately 10), reflecting the increased NADH/NAD+ ratio from impaired ETC function. Common causes include Complex I deficiency (most common), Complex IV deficiency, CoQ10 deficiency, and mtDNA mutations. LDH deficiency would cause LESS lactate, not more (C). Simple dehydration would not cause this pattern (D).

questions.question:
Researchers measure the proton-motive force (pmf) across the inner mitochondrial membrane under various conditions:

Condition | delta-psi (mV) | delta-pH | Total pmf (mV)
Control (State 3) | -150 | 0.5 | -180
Control (State 4) | -180 | 0.7 | -221
+ FCCP | -20 | 0.1 | -26
+ Valinomycin (K+ ionophore) | -50 | 1.5 | -139
+ Nigericin (K+/H+ antiporter) | -210 | 0.0 | -210

What do the valinomycin and nigericin experiments reveal about the two components of the pmf?
options: Valinomycin and nigericin both completely abolish the pmf, proving it is an artifact

Valinomycin collapses delta-psi (by allowing K+ to dissipate the charge gradient) but the compensatory increase in delta-pH maintains partial pmf; nigericin collapses delta-pH (by exchanging K+ for H+, dissipating the pH gradient) but delta-psi increases compensatorily — together, these experiments demonstrate that delta-psi and delta-pH are interconvertible components of a single thermodynamic driving force, and ATP synthase can be driven by either component alone
The ionophores have no effect on mitochondrial function
Only delta-psi contributes to ATP synthesis; delta-pH is irrelevant
questions.explanation: These classic experiments with ionophores elegantly demonstrate the thermodynamic equivalence of the two pmf components. VALINOMYCIN (K+ ionophore): Makes the inner membrane permeable to K+. K+ flows down its concentration gradient into the matrix, carrying positive charge inward and collapsing delta-psi from -150 to -50 mV. However, the proton pumps continue working, and the lost electrical component is partially compensated by an increased delta-pH (from 0.5 to 1.5 pH units). The total pmf decreases but is not abolished (-139 mV), and ATP synthesis continues (albeit at reduced rate). This proves delta-pH alone can drive ATP synthesis. NIGERICIN (K+/H+ antiporter): Exchanges K+ for H+ across the membrane (electroneutral, no net charge transfer). K+ flows in while H+ flows out, collapsing delta-pH from 0.5 to 0.0. Since no net charge moves, delta-psi is not directly affected and actually increases to -210 mV (compensatory increase). The total pmf is well-maintained (-210 mV), and ATP synthesis continues efficiently. This proves delta-psi alone can drive ATP synthesis. FCCP (protonophore): Collapses BOTH components simultaneously (delta-psi = -20 mV, delta-pH = 0.1), abolishing pmf (-26 mV) and stopping ATP synthesis. KEY INSIGHT: The pmf is a single thermodynamic entity (delta-p = delta-psi - 59delta-pH at 25C). ATP synthase responds to the TOTAL pmf regardless of its composition. Neither component alone is irrelevant (D).

questions.question:
A biochemistry student performs an experiment comparing the ATP yield from glucose versus glutamate as mitochondrial substrates:

Substrate | O2 consumed (nmol/min) | ATP produced (nmol/min) | P/O ratio
Glucose (complete oxidation) | 100 | 250 | 2.5
Glutamate + malate | 80 | 200 | 2.5
Succinate | 90 | 135 | 1.5
Palmitoyl-CoA + carnitine | 120 | 290 | 2.4

Why does succinate give a lower P/O ratio than glutamate/malate?
options: Succinate is a less energy-rich molecule than glutamate and therefore produces less total energy

Succinate donates electrons to Complex II (via FADH2), which does not pump protons — electrons enter the ETC at the ubiquinone level, bypassing Complex I; this means only Complexes III and IV pump protons (6 H+ per electron pair versus 10 H+ for NADH from glutamate/malate entering at Complex I), yielding 6/4 = 1.5 ATP versus 10/4 = 2.5 ATP per oxygen atom
Succinate inhibits ATP synthase, reducing the P/O ratio artificially
The lower P/O ratio for succinate is a measurement error because all substrates should yield identical P/O ratios
questions.explanation: The P/O ratio difference between NADH-linked and FADH2-linked substrates reflects the different entry points into the ETC: GLUTAMATE/MALATE → NADH (in matrix via glutamate dehydrogenase and malate dehydrogenase): NADH enters at Complex I → Q → Complex III → cyt c → Complex IV → O2. Protons pumped: Complex I (4) + Complex III (4) + Complex IV (2) = 10 H+. With 4 H+/ATP: P/O = 10/4 = 2.5. SUCCINATE → FADH2 (covalently bound in Complex II): FADH2 transfers electrons within Complex II to ubiquinone. Complex II does NOT pump protons. Electrons continue: Q → Complex III → cyt c → Complex IV → O2. Protons pumped: Complex III (4) + Complex IV (2) = 6 H+. With 4 H+/ATP: P/O = 6/4 = 1.5. PALMITOYL-CoA gives an intermediate P/O (2.4) because beta-oxidation produces both NADH (P/O = 2.5) and FADH2 (P/O = 1.5), and the weighted average of multiple rounds gives approximately 2.4. The key insight is that the ETC entry point determines how many proton-pumping complexes the electrons pass through, which directly determines the P/O ratio. Succinate does NOT inhibit ATP synthase (C). The P/O ratio difference is real and fundamental (D).

questions.question: A researcher discovers that cells from a patient with a suspected mitochondrial disease have reduced ATP production. To determine which ETC complex is deficient, what experimental approach should be used?
options: Measure total cellular ATP content after 24 hours and compare to normal cells

Perform spectrophotometric enzyme assays on isolated mitochondria using complex-specific substrates and inhibitors: measure Complex I activity (NADH + CoQ1 → NAD+ + CoQ1H2, rotenone-sensitive); Complex II activity (succinate + DCIP → fumarate + DCIPH2, inhibited by malonate); Complex III activity (reduced CoQ2 + cytochrome c (oxidized) → CoQ2 + cytochrome c (reduced), antimycin-sensitive); Complex IV activity (reduced cytochrome c + O2 → oxidized cytochrome c + H2O, cyanide-sensitive); normalize each to citrate synthase activity as a mitochondrial mass marker
Sequence the patient's nuclear genome to identify mutations in ETC subunit genes
Measure blood glucose levels as a proxy for mitochondrial function
questions.explanation: The gold standard for identifying which ETC complex is deficient is spectrophotometric enzyme activity measurement in isolated mitochondria or tissue homogenates, using complex-specific substrates and artificial electron acceptors: COMPLEX I (NADH:ubiquinone oxidoreductase): Measure rotenone-sensitive NADH oxidation using the artificial electron acceptor decylubiquinone (CoQ1). Follow NADH consumption at 340 nm. Activity = total NADH oxidation minus rotenone-insensitive activity. COMPLEX II (succinate:ubiquinone oxidoreductase): Measure succinate-dependent reduction of the artificial acceptor DCIP (2,6-dichlorophenolindophenol) at 600 nm, in the presence of rotenone (to block Complex I) and antimycin A (to block Complex III). COMPLEX III (ubiquinol:cytochrome c oxidoreductase): Measure antimycin A-sensitive reduction of cytochrome c (followed at 550 nm) using reduced decylubiquinone as electron donor. COMPLEX IV (cytochrome c oxidase): Measure cyanide-sensitive oxidation of reduced cytochrome c at 550 nm. NORMALIZATION: All activities are normalized to citrate synthase activity, which serves as a marker of mitochondrial mass/content. This corrects for differences in mitochondrial density between samples. The activity profile (e.g., low Complex I with normal II-IV) pinpoints the deficient complex. Total ATP measurement (A) cannot identify which complex is affected. Genomic sequencing (C) may miss mtDNA mutations and regulatory defects. Blood glucose (D) is an indirect and nonspecific marker.

questions.question: To investigate whether a newly isolated bacterial toxin inhibits glycolysis, the TCA cycle, or oxidative phosphorylation, a researcher designs an experiment using intact cells. Which set of measurements would best distinguish among these three targets?
options: Measure cell viability using a simple live/dead stain

Measure simultaneously: (1) extracellular acidification rate (ECAR, proxy for glycolytic rate/lactate production), (2) oxygen consumption rate (OCR, proxy for mitochondrial respiration), and (3) intracellular ATP levels — a glycolysis inhibitor would decrease ECAR with initially maintained OCR; a TCA cycle inhibitor would decrease OCR with compensatory increase in ECAR; an OXPHOS inhibitor would decrease OCR with compensatory increase in ECAR, but can be distinguished from TCA inhibition by adding an uncoupler (FCCP) which would restore OCR if only OXPHOS is blocked
Measure protein synthesis rates as a marker of cellular energy status
Simply incubate cells with the toxin and measure glucose consumption after 48 hours
questions.explanation: Modern metabolic phenotyping (e.g., using the Seahorse XF Analyzer) simultaneously measures OCR and ECAR in real time, providing a comprehensive metabolic profile: GLYCOLYSIS INHIBITOR (e.g., 2-deoxyglucose): ECAR decreases (less lactate produced). OCR may initially increase (cells try to compensate by increasing OXPHOS) or remain stable. ATP decreases if compensatory OXPHOS is insufficient. TCA CYCLE INHIBITOR (e.g., fluoroacetate blocking aconitase): OCR decreases (less NADH/FADH2 generated for ETC). ECAR increases (compensatory glycolysis upregulated via AMPK activation). Adding FCCP after the toxin would NOT restore OCR because the ETC lacks substrates (NADH/FADH2). OXPHOS INHIBITOR: Could be ETC inhibitor or ATP synthase inhibitor. OCR decreases. ECAR increases (compensatory glycolysis). KEY DISTINCTION from TCA inhibition: Adding FCCP after an ETC inhibitor does NOT restore OCR (ETC is blocked). Adding FCCP after an ATP synthase inhibitor (oligomycin) DOES restore OCR (ETC is intact, only coupling is blocked). If the toxin targets OXPHOS at the ATP synthase level: FCCP addition → OCR increases → confirms ATP synthase, not ETC, is the target. Cell viability (A) and protein synthesis (C) are too indirect. Glucose consumption over 48 hours (D) lacks temporal resolution and mechanistic specificity.

questions.question: A pharmacologist wants to test whether a candidate drug inhibits fatty acid beta-oxidation specifically, without affecting glucose oxidation. Which experimental design would provide the most definitive evidence?
options: Measure body weight changes in mice over several weeks of drug treatment

Measure CO2 production from C-14-labeled palmitate versus C-14-labeled glucose in isolated hepatocytes — if the drug specifically inhibits beta-oxidation, 14-CO2 from C-14-palmitate will decrease while 14-CO2 from C-14-glucose remains unchanged; additionally, measure acylcarnitine profiles (which accumulate upstream of beta-oxidation blocks) and free fatty acid levels in culture medium
Measure total cellular ATP levels and assume any decrease is due to beta-oxidation inhibition
Test whether the drug binds to CPT-I in a cell-free binding assay without measuring actual metabolic flux
questions.explanation: Isotopic tracer studies provide the most direct and specific measurement of metabolic pathway activity in intact cells. EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: (1) SPECIFICITY TEST: Incubate hepatocytes with either [U-14C]-palmitate (uniformly labeled) or [U-14C]-glucose, with and without the drug. Collect 14-CO2 in an alkaline trap (NaOH). If beta-oxidation is specifically inhibited: 14-CO2 from palmitate DECREASES (less fatty acid oxidation). 14-CO2 from glucose is UNCHANGED (glycolysis and TCA cycle are unaffected). This dual-substrate approach demonstrates pathway specificity. (2) MECHANISTIC CONFIRMATION: Measure acylcarnitine profiles (by LC-MS/MS) — specific beta-oxidation blocks cause accumulation of characteristic acylcarnitine species upstream of the block (e.g., CPT-I inhibition causes long-chain acylcarnitine accumulation; medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency causes C6-C10 acylcarnitine accumulation). (3) ADDITIONAL MARKERS: Measure free fatty acids (increase with impaired oxidation), ketone bodies (decrease with impaired hepatic beta-oxidation), and NADH/NAD+ ratio (should not change if only beta-oxidation is affected and cells can compensate with glucose). Body weight changes (A) are too slow and nonspecific. Total ATP measurement (C) cannot distinguish the source of ATP loss. Cell-free binding (D) cannot demonstrate functional inhibition of metabolic flux.

questions.question: A graduate student is studying the Warburg effect in cancer cells and wants to determine whether a tumor cell line relies more on glycolysis or oxidative phosphorylation for ATP production. Which approach provides the most informative metabolic profiling?
options: Measure the expression levels of glycolytic genes by RNA sequencing

Use the Seahorse XF Cell Mito Stress Test: sequentially add oligomycin (blocks ATP synthase, revealing glycolytic versus OXPHOS ATP production), FCCP (reveals maximal respiratory capacity), and rotenone/antimycin A (blocks all mitochondrial respiration, revealing non-mitochondrial OCR) — the resulting OCR and ECAR traces quantify basal respiration, ATP-linked respiration, proton leak, maximal respiration, spare respiratory capacity, and glycolytic rate
Simply count the number of mitochondria per cell using electron microscopy
Measure intracellular glucose concentration as a proxy for glycolytic rate
questions.explanation: The Seahorse XF Cell Mito Stress Test is the gold-standard functional assay for profiling cellular energy metabolism. The sequential drug addition protocol provides multiple metabolic parameters from a single experiment: BASAL MEASUREMENT: OCR and ECAR are measured before any drug addition, establishing the baseline metabolic phenotype. High ECAR/OCR ratio suggests glycolytic phenotype (Warburg); low ratio suggests oxidative phenotype. OLIGOMYCIN (ATP synthase inhibitor): OCR drops because ATP-linked respiration stops. The difference between basal and post-oligomycin OCR = ATP-linked respiration. ECAR typically increases (compensatory glycolysis). Any remaining OCR = proton leak (non-phosphorylating respiration). FCCP (uncoupler): OCR increases to maximal capacity (all thermodynamic restraint removed). The difference between FCCP-stimulated and basal OCR = spare respiratory capacity (reserve capacity the cell can call upon under stress). ROTENONE + ANTIMYCIN A (Complex I + III inhibitors): Blocks all mitochondrial electron transport. Residual OCR = non-mitochondrial oxygen consumption (e.g., cytoplasmic oxidases). Together, these measurements generate a comprehensive bioenergetic profile that quantitatively answers whether the cell relies more on glycolysis or OXPHOS. Gene expression (A) does not equal metabolic flux. Mitochondrial counts (C) do not reflect function. Glucose concentration (D) is difficult to interpret.

questions.question: Fluoroacetate is a toxic compound found in certain plants. It is converted to fluorocitrate in cells, which inhibits aconitase in the TCA cycle. What are the metabolic consequences of fluorocitrate poisoning?
options: Aconitase inhibition causes citrate to accumulate in the matrix, preventing further TCA cycle turns — this halts NADH/FADH2 production, collapses ETC flux and ATP synthesis; citrate accumulation also inhibits PFK-1 (slowing glycolysis) and citrate synthase (further blocking the cycle), leading to a catastrophic energy failure
Fluoroacetate is harmless because it cannot enter the mitochondrial matrix
Fluorocitrate specifically inhibits Complex IV of the ETC without affecting the TCA cycle
Fluorocitrate stimulates the TCA cycle, causing excessive ATP production
questions.explanation: Fluoroacetate poisoning (found in the South African plant Dichapetalum cymosum and the Australian plant Gastrolobium) is a classic example of lethal synthesis. Fluoroacetate is activated to fluoroacetyl-CoA, which condenses with oxaloacetate (via citrate synthase) to form fluorocitrate. Fluorocitrate is a potent competitive inhibitor of aconitase, blocking the conversion of citrate to isocitrate. METABOLIC CONSEQUENCES: (1) CITRATE ACCUMULATION: Without aconitase activity, citrate builds up in the mitochondrial matrix. (2) TCA CYCLE ARREST: The cycle cannot proceed past the aconitase step, so no NADH or FADH2 is produced from subsequent reactions (isocitrate DH, alpha-KGDH, succinate DH, malate DH). (3) ETC AND OXPHOS FAILURE: Without NADH/FADH2, the ETC has no electron donors, ATP synthesis stops. (4) GLYCOLYTIC INHIBITION: Citrate exported to the cytoplasm inhibits PFK-1, slowing glycolysis — the only remaining ATP source. (5) CITRATE SYNTHASE INHIBITION: Accumulated citrate product-inhibits citrate synthase, creating a complete TCA cycle block. The combination of TCA cycle arrest and glycolytic inhibition causes fatal energy depletion within hours. Fluorocitrate does NOT stimulate the cycle (A) or target Complex IV (C). Fluoroacetate does enter mitochondria and is metabolically activated (D).

questions.question: During aerobic respiration, water is produced at Complex IV. What is the detailed mechanism of oxygen reduction to water at the binuclear center?
options: Oxygen binds to the heme a3-CuB binuclear center and is reduced by four sequential one-electron transfers — the mechanism involves peroxy and ferryl intermediates (P and F states), and all four electrons are delivered before any partially reduced oxygen species (superoxide, peroxide) are released, preventing oxidative damage
Oxygen directly accepts two protons without any electron transfer
Water production occurs spontaneously at Complex III, not Complex IV
Oxygen is reduced in a single two-electron step to form hydrogen peroxide, which is then further reduced to water
questions.explanation: Complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase) catalyzes the four-electron reduction of O2 to 2 H2O, one of the most challenging reactions in biology because partially reduced oxygen species (superoxide, hydrogen peroxide, hydroxyl radical) are extremely toxic. The enzyme prevents their release through a carefully controlled mechanism at the binuclear center (heme a3 + CuB): STEP 1 (R→A): O2 binds to the reduced binuclear center (Fe2+-a3, Cu+B). STEP 2 (A→P): The O=O bond is cleaved in a concerted four-electron reduction. Two electrons come from Fe2+-a3 (oxidized to Fe4+=O, ferryl) and two from Cu+B and a nearby tyrosine residue (Tyr244 forms a radical). This produces the P (peroxy) intermediate with no free radical release. STEP 3 (P→F): One electron from cytochrome c (via CuA → heme a) reduces the tyrosine radical, forming the F (ferryl) state (Fe4+=O). One proton is taken up. STEP 4 (F→O): Another electron reduces the ferryl iron back to Fe3+, releasing H2O. The fully oxidized O state then accepts two more electrons to return to the reduced state for the next cycle. Crucially, all four electrons are transferred to oxygen before the binuclear center opens, preventing any partially reduced species from escaping. This is NOT a two-electron process (A). Proton transfer alone cannot reduce oxygen (C). Water production occurs at Complex IV, not III (D).

questions.question: The pyruvate dehydrogenase complex is regulated by covalent modification. Dichloroacetate (DCA), a drug used experimentally in cancer therapy and lactic acidosis, works by inhibiting PDH kinase. What is the expected metabolic effect?
options: DCA stimulates PDH kinase, increasing PDC phosphorylation and decreasing its activity

By inhibiting PDH kinase (PDK), DCA prevents phosphorylation of PDC, keeping it in the active (dephosphorylated) state — this increases pyruvate oxidation to acetyl-CoA, promotes entry into the TCA cycle and oxidative phosphorylation, reduces lactate production, and shifts metabolism from glycolysis toward mitochondrial oxidation
DCA has no effect on PDC regulation and works through an unrelated mechanism
DCA inactivates PDC by promoting its phosphorylation
questions.explanation: Dichloroacetate (DCA) is a structural analog of pyruvate that inhibits all four PDH kinase isoforms (PDK1-4). By inhibiting PDK, DCA prevents the phosphorylation of PDC, locking it in the active (dephosphorylated) form. Metabolic consequences: (1) INCREASED PYRUVATE OXIDATION: More pyruvate is converted to acetyl-CoA, increasing TCA cycle flux and NADH production for oxidative phosphorylation. (2) REDUCED LACTATE: Less pyruvate is available for LDH, decreasing lactate production. This is therapeutically useful in lactic acidosis (congenital or acquired). (3) CANCER APPLICATIONS: In cancer cells exhibiting the Warburg effect, DCA forces metabolism away from aerobic glycolysis toward mitochondrial oxidation. In some cancers, this reactivation of mitochondrial metabolism can restore apoptotic signaling (which is suppressed when mitochondria are underutilized) and reduce tumor growth. (4) In exercise physiology, DCA increases glucose oxidation and reduces lactate accumulation. DCA ACTIVATES PDC (not inactivates it, A). It INHIBITS PDK, not stimulates it (C). It clearly works through PDC regulation (D).

questions.question: Malonate is a competitive inhibitor of succinate dehydrogenase (Complex II). If malonate is added to actively respiring mitochondria using succinate as the sole substrate, what happens?
options: Malonate only affects Complex I and has no effect when succinate is the substrate
Malonate stimulates ATP synthase independently of the ETC

Oxygen consumption stops because malonate competitively inhibits succinate binding at the active site of Complex II — without electron input from succinate, the ubiquinone pool remains oxidized, Complexes III and IV have no electron donors, and the entire downstream ETC is halted; the proton gradient dissipates and ATP synthesis ceases
Electron transport accelerates because malonate provides additional electrons
questions.explanation: Malonate (CH2(COO-)2) is a dicarboxylic acid structurally similar to succinate (minus two hydrogens) that competitively inhibits succinate dehydrogenase by binding its active site without being oxidized. When succinate is the sole respiratory substrate: IMMEDIATE EFFECT: Malonate blocks succinate oxidation at Complex II, preventing FADH2 formation. No electrons enter the ubiquinone pool from Complex II. DOWNSTREAM CONSEQUENCES: Without reduced ubiquinone (QH2), Complex III has no substrate. Without reduced cytochrome c, Complex IV has no substrate. Oxygen consumption stops completely. ENERGETIC CONSEQUENCES: Proton pumping ceases at Complexes III and IV. The proton gradient gradually dissipates through normal proton leak. ATP synthase stops when the pmf drops below the threshold for ATP synthesis. COMPETITION: Because malonate is a competitive inhibitor, its effect can be overcome by adding excess succinate (increasing [succinate]/[malonate] ratio). This was historically used to confirm the competitive nature of the inhibition. Malonate does NOT accelerate anything (A). It specifically inhibits Complex II, not Complex I (C). It does not stimulate ATP synthase (D). This experiment was crucial in Albert Szent-Gyorgyi's and Hans Krebs's elucidation of the TCA cycle.

questions.question: The concept of 'respiratory control' refers to the regulation of mitochondrial oxygen consumption by ADP availability. Which of the following best explains this phenomenon?
options: In tightly coupled mitochondria, electron transport and ATP synthesis are linked through the proton gradient — when ADP is scarce (State 4), ATP synthase slows, protons accumulate, the pmf increases, and the resulting thermodynamic back-pressure on the ETC slows electron flow and O2 consumption; when ADP is available (State 3), ATP synthase activity increases, proton flux dissipates some pmf, and the ETC accelerates
ADP directly binds to and activates Complex IV, increasing its affinity for oxygen
Respiratory control means that oxygen directly regulates ADP production
ADP inhibits the electron transport chain to prevent wasteful oxygen consumption
questions.explanation: Respiratory control is one of the most fundamental demonstrations of chemiosmotic coupling. In well-coupled mitochondria, the rate of oxygen consumption is tightly controlled by ADP availability through the proton gradient: STATE 4 (no ADP, resting): ATP synthase cannot operate without ADP as substrate. Protons pumped by the ETC accumulate in the IMS, increasing the pmf. As pmf rises, it becomes thermodynamically more costly for Complexes I, III, and IV to pump additional protons against the steeper gradient. Electron transport slows, and oxygen consumption decreases to a basal rate (mainly from proton leak). STATE 3 (ADP added, active): ADP + Pi enter the matrix (via ANT and PiC). ATP synthase binds ADP and catalyzes ATP synthesis, allowing protons to flow back through the Fo channel. This partially dissipates the pmf, reducing the back-pressure on the ETC. The ETC accelerates, pumping protons faster, consuming more O2. The respiratory control ratio (RCR = State 3 OCR/State 4 OCR) measures the tightness of coupling. A high RCR (typically 3-10) indicates well-coupled mitochondria. Damaged or uncoupled mitochondria have low RCR (approaching 1). ADP does NOT bind Complex IV (A). O2 does not regulate ADP production (C). ADP activates the overall system, it does not inhibit the ETC (D).

questions.question: What is the significance of the Gibbs free energy change becoming less negative at each successive step of the electron transport chain?
options: The decreasing energy release means the later complexes are less important for ATP production

Each complex in the ETC releases a similar amount of energy — enough to pump protons but not so much that energy is wasted as heat; this stepwise release through multiple complexes captures more of the total available energy as proton-motive force compared to a single large energy release
The stepwise energy release is a design flaw that reduces the efficiency of oxidative phosphorylation
The energy at each step becomes positive, meaning later steps are endergonic
questions.explanation: The total free energy available from NADH oxidation to O2 is -219 kJ/mol. Rather than releasing this energy in a single explosive step (which would largely be dissipated as heat), the ETC parcels it out through a series of thermodynamically favorable steps: Complex I (NADH → Q): delta-G approximately -69 kJ/mol (pumps 4 H+). Complex III (QH2 → cyt c): delta-G approximately -36 kJ/mol (pumps 4 H+ via Q-cycle). Complex IV (cyt c → O2): delta-G approximately -110 kJ/mol (pumps 2 H+, but also uses energy for the kinetically challenging O2 reduction). The energy released at each step is sufficient to pump protons against the approximately 200 mV gradient, but the stepwise approach allows more of the total energy to be captured productively. This is analogous to a hydroelectric dam releasing water through a series of turbines at different elevations, rather than letting it all fall at once. If the total energy were released in one step, most would be dissipated as heat (thermal energy), and only one proton-pumping site could be utilized. By distributing the energy across three pumping sites (Complexes I, III, IV), the cell captures approximately 10 protons per NADH, generating enough pmf for approximately 2.5 ATP. The later complexes ARE important (B). The delta-G at each step is negative (C). The stepwise design is an evolutionary optimization, not a flaw (D).

questions.question: Pyruvate carboxylase is a key anaplerotic enzyme that replenishes oxaloacetate in the TCA cycle. What activates this enzyme, and why is this regulation logical?
options: Pyruvate carboxylase is activated by AMP, signaling that the cell needs more energy production through the TCA cycle
Pyruvate carboxylase is constitutively active and requires no allosteric regulation
NADH inhibits pyruvate carboxylase to prevent excessive OAA production

Acetyl-CoA is an essential allosteric activator of pyruvate carboxylase — when acetyl-CoA accumulates (from beta-oxidation or amino acid catabolism), it signals that more oxaloacetate is needed to condense with the excess acetyl-CoA and maintain TCA cycle flux; without OAA replenishment, acetyl-CoA cannot enter the cycle
questions.explanation: Pyruvate carboxylase (PC) catalyzes: pyruvate + CO2 + ATP → oxaloacetate + ADP + Pi. This biotin-dependent enzyme is the most important anaplerotic reaction in mammalian cells.
